Stocks kicked off a short trading week with a bang Monday in a show of resurgence after last week's lackluster action. The S&P 500 rallied 1.2% and regained its 50-day moving average. It has already recouped a little more than half of last week's 2.2% loss. Helped by megacaps Apple (AAPL) and Google (GOOGL), the Nasdaq rose 1.1%. Chips and…

Driven by strong 2014 auto sales, CarMax (KMX) posted accelerating earnings and revenue growth in fiscal Q3 and is now trying to motor through a new flat base buy point. Fellow car dealer stocks Asbury Automotive Group (ABG) and AutoNation (AN) topped earnings estimates earlier this month, so see if CarMax can do the same when it reports fourth-quarter numbers…

AutoNation's  (AN) fourth-quarter earnings and revenue topped estimates in what the company called its best quarter ever. U.S. auto sales overall were strong in 2014 as increasingly confident consumers — amid lower unemployment, lower gas prices and continuing economic recovery — stepped up buying. The nation's top auto dealership chain by revenue said Q4 earnings per share rose 24%…

Car dealers have seen solid growth in recent quarters thanks to a rebounding U.S. auto market. That's expected to continue for top players like AutoNation (AN), Asbury Automotive Group (ABG), Penske Automotive Group (PAG) and Lithia Motors (LAD) when they report fourth-quarter results over the next few weeks.

AutoNation is slated to report its Q4 results after the close on Feb. 3. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect EPS of 91 cents, up 10% from the prior year. Revenue is seen climbing 9% to $4.9 billion. If those results hold up, it would continue a streak of double-digit earnings growth that dates back at least three years.
Asbury is due to report its fourth-quarter earnings before the open a day later. It is expected to log earnings of $1.01 a share, up 15% from the prior year. Revenue should climb 8% to $1.5 billion.

Penske is scheduled to report its fourth-quarter earnings before the open on Feb. 11. Analysts expect the company to log an 18% EPS gain to 80 cents and a 14% revenue increase to $4.4 billion. If Penske meets or exceeds those expectations, it will mark the seventh straight quarter of double-digit sales and earnings growth.

All car dealers have gotten a lift from a revitalized auto market. According to Autodata, an industry research and tracking firm, about 16.5 million new vehicles were sold in the U.S. last year, the highest total since 2006.
Last week, industry consultants J.D. Power and LMC Automotive said January U.S. auto sales should rise more than 12% from a low base in the prior year.

While those trends have boosted results at Lithia Motors, the company got an additional lift last quarter when it closed its $362 million buyout of DCH Auto Group in a deal that gave Lithia its first presence in the eastern U.S.

Thanks to that buyout, Lithia is expected to report a 65% sales gain when it reports Q4 results during the third week of February. That's nearly double the previous biggest increase over the last dozen quarters. Earnings are expected to rise 21% to $1.19 a share.

Lithia has an IBD Composite Rating of 96. That puts it atop IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Automobile group, which ranks No. 77 out of the 197 industries tracked. Other stocks in the group with Composite Ratings above 90 include CarMax (KMX), Penske, Asbury and AutoNation.Car dealers have seen solid growth in recent quarters thanks to a rebounding U.S. auto market. Growth stock mutual funds have lagged value and core funds, which invest in both growth and value stocks, over the past 15 years. That's largely because of growth mutual funds' sharp decline in the dot-com bear market of 2000-02. Look how an investment of $10,000 on Dec. 31, 1999, would have done in each type of fund, according to Morningstar…

There's nothing like a good quarterly report to send a stock flying to a new high on big volume, perhaps gapping out of a base. That happened to some growth names Friday. A prime example is Red Hat (RHT), maker of open-source software such as the Linux operating system. Earnings delivered Thursday evening were flat but better than analysts expected.…

A lot of car dealers claim to offer no-hassle, no-haggle shopping. Then you get on the lot and somebody tries to sell you $20,000 worth of bells and whistles you don't want. TrueCar (TRUE), a May IPO , tries to take that scenario out of the equation by prohibiting dealers in its network from trying to upsell customers who have…
Stocks pulsed higher at the start of trade Friday, with company news squarely in the spotlight.
The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 climbed 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq stuck to a 0.1% gain.
Volume was sharply mixed, up 11% on the NYSE and 25% lower on the Nasdaq, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.
The stock market today opened to some notable events.

Apple (AAPL) eased a bit less than 1% as Apple stores worldwide began taking orders for the new Apple Watch. All devices in the U.S. had "almost entirely sold out" in less than six hours, according to the Apple intelligence site 9TO5Mac. Minimum order times were four to six weeks, the site reported. Apple shares are sitting on their 10-week moving average within a seven-week flat base.

General Electric (GE) surged 9%, hauling the Dow higher. The diversified heavyweight announced a restructuring program that includes plans to divest most of its GE Capital service operations over the next two years. The company said it had lined up buyers, led by Blackstone Group (BX) and Wells Fargo (WFC), for most of its commercial real estate portfolio. It announced a $50 billion share buyback initiative. GE leapt past highs from February and November, sending shares to their highest mark since June.

Netflix (NFLX) climbed 2% after Citigroup upgraded shares to buy from neutral and raised its price target to 525 from 409. The gain boosted shares back above their 10-week moving average and put the stock up 8% for the week.

Citrix Systems (CTXS) dropped more than 4% after management trimmed the software developer's Q1 earnings and revenue guidance after Thursday's close. The company cited an unexpected impact from its restructuring. William Blair downgraded the stock to market perform from outperform. Shares have been consolidating since September.

Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) jumped 4% in heavy trade, retaking its converged 10- and 40-week moving averages. The stock is in a two-month flat base.Stocks pulsed higher at the start of trade Friday, with company news squarely in the spotlight.The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 climbed 0.2% apiece. Stocks remained firmly higher in early afternoon trading Thursday as more highly rated names staged breakouts.The Nasdaq led the way, up 1.6%, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.4% and the S&P 500 added 1.3%. Volume was tracking mixed in the stock market today, higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.Tyler Technologies (TYL) shot 9% higher in heavy trading, breaking out past a 97.63 buy point in a cup-with-handle pattern. The company on Wednesday reported third-quarter earnings and sales figures that beat analysts' expectations.Epam Systems (EPAM)broke out past a 44.46 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern, pushing 4% higher in heavy volume.Automobile sellers were the top performing industry group in the market today. Group member CarMax (KMX) rose 8% in huge trading on news that it will expand its share repurchase program.Forty-nine of the IBD 50 stocks were higher at the halfway point. Under Armour (UA)was the lone exception, down modestly after trimming losses. It reported quarterly earnings and sales above estimates, but some analysts were concerned by rising costs. The stock is consolidating below its 50-day moving average and is in the seventh week of a new base.New issue Alibaba (BABA) pushed 3% higher and is climbing the right side of an IPO base with 99.80 buy point.
Add cars to Warren Buffett's portfolio.
Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) agreed to buy Van Tuyl Group, the nation's largest privately-owned automobile dealership group and the fifth largest among all U.S. car dealership groups.
And Berkshire Hathaway's chairman and CEO won't stop there.
In an interview with CNBC, Warren Buffett said that he sees long-term value in auto dealerships, which he said he could help consolidate. "I fully expect we'll buy a lot more dealerships over time."

Berkshire Class B shares rose 0.6% to 137.42 on the stock market today, while shares of Lithia Motors (LAD) and AutoNation (AN) surged. The former rose 7.7% to 79.09, while the latter — the nation's largest car dealership chain — jumped 5.9%
CarMax (KMX) shares rose 0.5% to 45.56. Sonic Automotive (SAH) also gained, rising 2.8% to 24.70.
After the Berkshire deal closes, Van Tuyl will be renamed Berkshire Hathaway Automotive and will be headquartered in Dallas. Financial terms weren't disclosed.

Van Tuyl Group CEO Larry Van Tuyl said in a statement that his company was "very pleased to have one of the world's most respected companies, Berkshire Hathaway, assume ownership of our company."Add cars to Warren Buffett's portfolio.Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) agreed to buy Van Tuyl Group, the nation's largest privately-owned automobile dealership group and the fifth largest among all U.S. car dealership groups.And Berkshire Hathaway's chairman and CEO won't stop there.In an interview with CNBC, Warren Buffett said that he sees long-term value in auto dealerships, which he said he could help consolidate. "I fully expect we'll buy a lot more dealerships over time."Berkshire Class B shares rose 0.6% to 137.42 on the stock market today, while shares of Lithia Motors (LAD) and AutoNation (AN) surged. The former rose 7.7% to 79.09, while the latter — the nation's largest car dealership chain — jumped 5.9%CarMax (KMX) shares rose 0.5% to 45.56. Sonic Automotive (SAH) also gained, rising 2.8% to 24.70.After the Berkshire deal closes, Van Tuyl will be renamed Berkshire Hathaway Automotive and will be headquartered in Dallas. Financial terms weren't disclosed.Van Tuyl Group CEO Larry Van Tuyl said in a statement that his company was "very pleased to have one of the world's most respected companies, Berkshire Hathaway, assume ownership of our company."
Shares of CarMax (KMX), the nation's largest used car seller, plunged Tuesday after it reported lower-than-expected second-quarter profit amid rising new car sales.
Earnings rose 3% to 64 cents per share, missing estimates by 3 cents. Revenue increased 11% to $3.6 billion, topping forecasts of $3.57 billion.
Growth in comparable-store unit sales at its used car lots nearly ground to a halt, rising just 0.2%, down from 15.9% growth a year earlier.
However, used car dollar sales rose 10.6% to $2.92 billon, and total used car unit sales were up 6.3%. New car sales rose 16.6% to $69.9 million.
Focusing almost exclusively on used cars helped CarMax grow rapidly during and after the recession. But recent quarters have seen a surge of new car sales as consumers' finances improve.
CarMax shares were down 8.5% on the stock market today.

The share of vehicles financed by third-party subprime providers and those financed by CarMax Auto Finance, which serves consumers who typically go to third-party subprime providers, shrank to 13.8% in Q2 from 18.5% a year ago.
Among other large auto dealers, Penske Auto Group (PAG) and Asbury Automotive Group (ABG) were both down fractionally. Small-town auto dealership operator Lithia Motors (LAD) eased 1%.

Stocks finished the day down moderately, with the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 lower for the third straight day. Volume was running lighter than the previous day, according to preliminary figures.The Nasdaq was down 0.4%; the S&P 500 fell 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.7%.In the stock market today, among IBD 50 stocks, 13 were higher and 37 were lower. Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP) was the top performer, up more than 6% in big volume. There were reports that Allergan (AGN) was in talks to acquire the company. Allergan was up nearly 2%.Also, among drugmakers, Actavis (ACT) spiked midday and hit a new all-time high on chatter that Pfizer (PFE) is interested in buying it.The worst performer was Emerge Energy (EMES), which plunged through its 50-day line in heavy volume and was down more than 6%. The stock had nearly tripled since breaking out of a base in March. This was its first trip well below the support line.CarMax (KMX) gapped down and finished nearly 10% lower after a disappointing quarterly report. Analysts said that subprime lending had been a major growth driver for the company and such lending is slowing down.Chinese online retailer Vipshop (VIPS) rose more than 4% in above-average volume, but it continues to find resistance at its 50-day moving average. The stock may be building a new base.

Shares of AutoNation (AN) motored higher after reporting its best July sales since 2006 amid replacements for the fleet of aging vehicles on U.S. roads and continued strong sales of luxury cars. The nation's No. 1 auto retailer said July sales rose 8% vs. the same month a year ago to 27,484 new vehicles. On a same-store basis, unit sales…
With cars selling at their top pace since 2006, IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Automobile industry group is riding high, ranked No. 15 of 197 industries tracked.
But a key member may be approaching a road bump.

The group is home to names such as CarMax (KMX) and AutoNation (AN), the largest by market cap. In a research note released Friday, Sterne Agee lowered its 2014 earnings estimates on the group's seventh-largest car dealer, Group 1 Automotive (GPI), citing volatility. But the brokerage remains upbeat on the dealer group as a whole.

"While we remain positive on GPI and the dealer group on a long-term basis, we believe current market prices and continued volatility in Brazil could limit some of the upside," Sterne Agee analyst Michael Ward noted.
Group 1 dipped more than 2% in early trading in the stock market today.

Houston-based Group 1 owns and operates 152 auto dealerships, 193 franchises and 37 collision centers in the U.S., the U.K. and Brazil. Last quarter, it logged a 3% year-over-year earnings decline — its second dip in the last four quarters.

Ward lowered his full-year 2014 earnings estimates on Group 1 to $5.30 a share from $5.60 "to reflect weaker-than-expected second-quarter earnings and ongoing weakness in Brazil." He also revised his 2015 earnings estimate to $5.80 a share from $5.90 "to reflect the market weakness in South America."
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Group 1 to log 2014 earnings per share of $5.50, up from $4.96 in 2013. They see 2015 profit rising 17% to $6.45 a share.

Ward noted that Group 1 "has been among the most aggressive in the dealer group, using acquisitions as a way to enhance growth." Deals this quarter include the July buyout of a pair of Chevrolet and Mazda dealerships in Houston and the August acquisition of a Mercedez-Benz dealership near San Antonio.

At the same time, Ward said he believes that U.S. sales "can be sustained at a relatively high level for at least three to five years, which in our view will produce record financial results for the industry."

On Thursday, Ward noted that U.S. light vehicle sales increased 5.4% in August — or up 9.3%, adjusting for one less selling day — to 1.58 million units. Sales totaled 17.5 million units on a seasonally adjusted annual rate basis, or SAAR.

"The U.S. SAAR in August reached its highest level since January 2006," Ward wrote. "The sales total was about 5% higher than expectations heading into the release," thanks mainly to stronger-than-expected sales at Chrysler, Honda (HMC) and Toyota Motor (TM).

Highly rated companies in the auto retail/wholesale group include Lithia Motors (LAD), with an IBD Composite Rating of 99; and Asbury Automotive Group (ABG), with a Composite Rating of 98.With cars selling at their top pace since 2006, IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Automobile industry group is riding high, ranked No. 15 of 197 industries tracked.But a key member may be approaching a road bump.The group is home to names such as CarMax (KMX) and AutoNation (AN), the largest by market cap. Stock futures welled higher Friday, as the dollar rose and quarterly reports fueled some strong premarket moves.
Dow futures were 69.9 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 19.7 points. S&P 500 futures jumped 12 points.

The stock market today wraps up a volatile week with the S&P 500 recovered from a 1.5% dip to open Friday with a 2.9% gain so far for the week. The Nasdaq turned a 2.2% loss into a 2% advance. Both open within striking distance of new highs.

The market's status remains in correction, but investor attitudes shifted considerably during the week, alongside the Federal Reserve's restrained policy announcement Wednesday and the willingness of Russia's central bank to deploy capital in order to bolster the faltering ruble.
Options expirations are likely to drive volume higher Friday, but the week's economic calendar has largely blown itself out.

But heavy mixing action in premarket trade received a brisk stir from earnings reports. Blackberry (BBRY) dropped 5%. Finish Line (FINL) toppled 10%. Carmax (KMX) climbed 7% and Pier 1 Imports (PIR) jumped 6%.

Red Hat (RHT) spiked 11% after a flat earnings performance in the third quarter bested expectations for a decline. Revenue growth of 15% comfortably topped consensus views. Demand for larger sales "was exceptional," management said in a statement, "setting new records in number of deals over $5 million in a quarter and deals over $10 million in a Q3."
Red Hat has been struggling to clear a cup base buy point of 62.79 since mid-November.

Blue chip shoe maker Nike (NKE) dropped more than 2% after reporting its fiscal second quarter results late Thursday. Earnings and revenue growth both easily topped consensus forecasts, but future orders slowed for the first time in four quarters, flagging a possible slowdown ahead.
Nike share had pulled back for a test of 10-week support, but remain extended after clearing a flat base in September.

Overseas, Europe's markets traded modestly lower near midday but tracking toward healthy gains, overall, for the week. In Asia, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 jumped 2.4% Friday to seize a 1.4% gain for the week. China's major indexes rose more than 1% Friday, leaving Hong Kong's Hang Seng index flat and the Shanghai Composite up 5.8% for the week.

The dollar continued to rise broadly. Oil prices warmed 1% or so, but remained sharply lower for the week. Stocks made gains for the third straight day Friday, but they lacked the power of Wednesday's and Thursday's advances, even though volume was higher because of quadruple witching.
The Nasdaq rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 gained 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average was ahead 0.2%.
A few earnings reports and a new issue dominated the session.

CarMax (KMX) gapped up and closed more than 10% higher in the stock market today after reporting a 28% increase in earnings from a year ago. It was the same with work uniform provider Cintas (CTAS), which gapped up and closed nearly 5% higher after reporting a 26% earnings gain.

Among IBD 50 stocks, 30 were higher and 20 were lower. The worst performer was Foot Locker (FL), down 7% in sympathy with Finish Line (FINL), which reported an earnings decline and lowered guidance, citing a weak retail environment.
Fellow sneaker maker Nike (NKE) also fell nearly 2%, but finished the day in the upper half of its daily range.
Biotech company Juno Therapeutics (JUNO) came public with fireworks, closing up 46% from a 24 offering price.

Depressed oil and gas industry groups were the day's best performers as the price of oil rose nearly 7%. Retail stocks were among the worst performers.Stocks made gains for the third straight day Friday, but they lacked the power of Wednesday's and Thursday's advances, even though volume was higher because of quadruple witching.The Nasdaq rose 0.4%, the S&P 500 gained 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average was ahead 0.2%.A few earnings reports and a new issue dominated the session. Stocks rebounded and moved to fresh session highs late Friday.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each added 0.4%, while the Dow Jones industrial average inched up 0.2%. Volume was tracking heavier in the stock market today boosted by quadruple witching of options and futures.Nike (NKE) weighed on the Dow, falling 2%, after the company reported earnings late Thursday. Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) outperformed, rising 2% as crude oil soared more than 4%.Carmax (KMX) blasted up 11% to a new all-time high after reporting third-quarter results before the open. The used car seller's earnings climbed 28% on a 16% rise in revenue, topping analyst forecasts.Biotechs Gilead Sciences (GILD) and Biogen (BIIB) posted big gains in active trading. Biogen climbed 2% touching a new high. The stock is in buying range after clearing a choppy consolidation with 347.85 buy point.Endurance (EIGI), a provider of cloud-based marketing software, climbed 4% to a new high. The stock has added 17% for the week. Average daily trading volume has risen steadily over the past two months to more than 400,000 shares a day. The stock has a 97 Composite Rating and boosted third quarter earnings 59% on a 21% jump in sales.On the downside, toy makers Hasbro (HAS) and Mattel (MAT) sold-off hard after an analyst note said both firms appear to be losing market share to private competitors. Mattel fell 6% in huge trade and is near a 52-week low. Hasbro also shed 6%.
Holiday sales can make or break companies in retailing. But not all of them bank on the busiest shopping season of the year to get them over the hump.

Analysts at Wells Fargo Securities found six companies among 67 they cover in retailing whose businesses peak at other times of the year: Nike (NKE), Tractor Supply (TSCO), Citi Trends (CTRN), CarMax (KMX) and women's apparel retailers Ann (ANN) and Chico's FAS (CHS).
Sales volume at Nike is largest in its May quarter, likely because of shipment timings into its big summer selling season, the analysts pointed out.

Value-priced apparel and footwear retailer Citi Trends takes in the greatest amount of sales in its April-ending first quarter due to full-price spending in the Easter/spring season. Tax refunds early in the year also help, the analysts noted.
Ann's best quarter is usually in the third quarter, the analysts said. Per-share earnings have certainly outperformed then, while its January-ending first quarter usually is the weakest of the year.
Chico's best sales quarter "tends to alternate" among the non-holiday periods, the analysts noted.
Farm-supply chain Tractor Supply does best in spring — no surprise. Used-car chain CarMax shines in its May-ending quarter.
Having the best sales in non-holiday quarters has rewarded four of the six stocks, which all sport relatively high ratings from IBD based on earnings, stock performance and other metrics.
Nike leads with a Composite Rating of 96 out of a possible 99, followed by CarMax with an 88, Tractor Supply with an 84 and Citi Trends with a 74.

The lowest rated are Ann and Chico's, at 46 and 45 respectively.Holiday sales can make or break companies in retailing. Breakouts in health care, technology, utilities and other sectors highlighted Monday's new highs. One of the cleanest-looking breakouts belonged to AmerisourceBergen (ABC). The drug distribution company rose 1.17 to 79.45, clearing a 79.23 buy point from a flat base. It was a bullish move for AmerisourceBergen ahead of its results for the September-ended quarter, which come out Thursday. Analysts expect…

The stock market fell again Tuesday, leaving its outlook no less murky than it has been on other days lately. The Nasdaq slipped 0.4% and the S&P 500 0.6%. Selling picked up in the final 15 minutes as both indexes closed at session lows. The IBD 50 fell only 0.1%, but that was its third straight drop. Leading stocks have…

A new report from Sterne Agee offered a bullish outlook for car dealers Wednesday morning, a day after No. 1 U.S. dealer AutoNation (AN) topped quarterly earnings views and the same day Penske Automotive Group (PAG) met EPS estimates and announced a new ownership stake.Analyst Michael Ward, who follows auto retail stocks for Sterne Agee, said he expects U.S. light vehicle sales "can be sustained at a relatively high level for at least three to five years, which in our view will produce record financial results for the industry."He added that "a range-bound and extended cycle provides an optimal operating environment for the industry, and investors should benefit from shareholder-friendly capital allocation decisions over the next few years."Ward also raised his annual earnings estimates on AutoNation, which topped third-quarter sales and earnings views on Tuesday.He now expects the company to post full-year 2014 EPS of $3.40 — up from a previous estimate of $3.35 — "to reflect the third-quarter beat and greater-than-expected share repurchase." Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect full-year earnings of $3.37 a share.For 2015, Ward raised his EPS estimates on AutoNation to $3.65 from $3.60. That compares with consensus estimates of $3.75.AutoNation is the biggest U.S. dealership in terms of annual revenue, though CarMax (KMX) ranks No. 1 in market cap. AutoNation shares fell slightly to 55.44 in afternoon trading on the stock market today after closing up 7% on Tuesday.Meanwhile, Penske logged Q3 earnings of 85 cents a share, up 16% from the prior year and in line with views. Revenue climbed 18% to $4.4 billion, topping estimates. Same-store retail revenue increased 11%. Penske shares were down 3% in afternoon trade.Penske also signed an agreement to acquire a majority stake in the Around The Clock (ATC) Freightliner Group, a heavy-duty retail truck dealership group. When that deal closes, Penske's ownership interest will climb to 88% from 27%.IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Automobile group ranks No. 92 of 197 industries tracked. The top-rated stocks are Asbury Automotive Group (ABG) and Lithia Motors (LAD), which both have Composite Ratings of 92.

A drop in used-car values damaged third-quarter earnings at Lithia Motors (LAD) and caused it to reduce per-share earnings guidance well below Wall Street views, the Oregon-based auto dealer said Monday, sending the IBD 50 stock crashing 19%. Stocks remained lower in early afternoon trading Tuesday as an analyst warning on the new Apple iPhone hurt shares of the company and its suppliers.The Nasdaq was off 0.6% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were off 0.2%.Volume was tracking lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq. Declining stocks had a small edge over advancers on the NYSE while the losers led by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq.Solar energy, automaker, staffing and dairy product companies were among the poorest performers in the stock market today. Tesla (TSLA) skidded more than 3%, sinking deeper below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Metal, retail, utility and real estate investment trust industry groups were some of the best Tuesday.Some suppliers of the Apple (AAPL) iPhone were lower after Credit Suisse warned that the company was cutting back component orders for the iPhone 6S model.Apple shares gapped down to a 3% loss in above-average volume. Cirrus Logic (CRUS) slid 7% in busy trading and fell below the 50-day moving average. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) gapped below its 50-day moving average as it shed 6% in heavy trading.On the plus side, Ruth's Hospitality (RUTH), better known as Ruth's Chris Steak House, cleared the 16.96 buy point of a double-bottom base in active trading.The company beat Q3 earnings expectations a couple of weeks ago as EPS jumped 33%. The restaurant industry group, though, has been trending lower in IBD's group rankings.
Leery about picking stocks on your own?
Novice traders with little knowledge or confidence to pick winning stocks may benefit by first seeing what great mutual funds are buying.

Funds rule the market. After all, they spend millions, even billions, of dollars buying individual stocks. They're armed with large research staffs whose sole job is to come up with the best stocks among the thousands offered.
All investors would do well to follow what the big mutual funds are buying and selling with conviction.
Demand The Best

It's not enough to follow just any mutual fund. IBD ranks mutual fund performance over the past 36 months with letter grades of A+ to E. IBD recommends that you focus on funds with A+, A or A- ratings.
Top funds outperform the S&P 500 while offering protection in a declining market, as their managers actively try to reduce risk by adjusting the fund's holdings.
Fidelity Magellan Fund has been a long-time leader. It's rated A and has climbed 13% this year, outpacing the S&P 500's 10% gain.
The fund holds 165 stocks. Big holdings include Apple (AAPL), JPMorgan Chase (JPM),Bank of America (BAC) and Google (GOOGL).
Of those, Apple and Google have an IBD Composite Rating of 80 or higher. The chart accompanying this column shows the highest-rated stocks that Magellan has among its top 30 holdings.

Don't blindly buy what the funds are buying. The best stocks that get accumulated by the strongest-performing funds will form good bases and set up buy points within those bases. That's the correct time to buy such stocks. (Go to IBD University at Investors.com to learn about the seven basic base patterns and how to buy correctly.)
Investors should make sure their objectives fit the goals of the fund.
For example, the Fidelity Magellan Fund invests in large-cap growth stocks, while the TIAA-CREF Enhanced Large Cap Growth Fund , also rated A, primarily invests in large domestic companies.

The 297-stock TIAA fund, whose top holdings are Apple, Google, Microsoft (MSFT) and Verizon (VZ), has risen 9% this year, slightly underperforming the Magellan fund and the S&P 500. However, that could be due to TIAA's emphasis on relatively more conservative large-cap stocks. During the market's sharp fall in 2008-09, the TIAA fund fell less than both the Magellan Fund and the S&P 500.

Meanwhile, lower-rated funds tend to underperform during bull markets and bear markets. For example, Wells Fargo Advantage Growth Fund , rated C+, is up just 3% this year. It focuses on large-cap growth stocks. The fund's top holdings include Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), Union Pacific (UNP), CarMax (KMX) and Google.

Invesco Midcap Growth Fund is also underperforming the S&P 500 this year, up just 6%. Its biggest holdings include Amphenol (APH), Actavis (ACT), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) and Alexion Pharmaceuticals.

Past performance is no guarantee of future returns. IBD's ratings cover just three years of performance. Investors should also check a fund's long-term performance while conducting stock research.Leery about picking stocks on your own?Novice traders with little knowledge or confidence to pick winning stocks may benefit by first seeing what great mutual funds are buying.Funds rule the market. IBD's ratings cover just three years of performance. Investors should also check a fund's long-term performance while conducting stock research.
Big-cap stocks continued to trade near all-time highs in early afternoon trading Friday as a dovish Federal Reserve continued to fuel a rally that is carrying into its sixth day.
Volume was running higher due to options expiration.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2%; the S&P 500 gained 01% and the Nasdaq rose fractionally. The Dow and the S&P 500 were trading just off all-time highs set earlier in the day.

With little economic news to energize traders, earnings news and takeover talk took the spotlight. Oracle (ORCL) gapped down and was trading 5% lower in heavy volume after reporting earnings of 92 cents a share, a 6% increase from a year ago but below estimates. Revenue also missed.
The big winner was CarMax (KMX). Shares vaulted 17% after the company reported EPS of 76 cents a share, a 19% increase from a year ago and above estimates. Sales rose 13% to$3.75 billion.
Irish drugmaker Shire (SHPG) gapped up and was trading 16% higher after rejecting another bid from rival AbbVie (ABBV). AbbVie was trading down 0.6% after a volatile morning.

Shire was the best performing stock in the IBD 50, but KapStone Paper and Packaging (KS) was the second best, up 4% in volume well above average. Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq held on to its 0.5% advance.
Volume was soft, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 90% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today is rebounding, but still correcting, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 deep in the hole for the week. The market received an early assist today from China, where some rule changes and federally engineered buying helped lift markets to their first healthy close of the week.
December hiring in the U.S. was also a factor, as the Labor Department reported payrolls jumped by 292,000 during the month — far above expectations.
Wholesale inventories dropped 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said. That was even with October's slip and below expectations for no change.

The market will have an ear out for post-payroll comments from San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who speaks at 11:30 a.m. ET, and from Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker, on the docket for a 1 p.m. speech.
Apple (AAPL) and DuPont (DD) raced to the head of the Dow, up nearly 2% each. Wynn Resorts (WYNN)headed the S&P 500 with a 4% gain.
Gap (GPS) cratered 7% after announcing late Thursday its December same-store sales slipped 5% vs. consensus views for a 3.5% decline.

Chipmaker and Apple supplier Qorvo (QRVO) dropped 4%. The Greensboro, N.C. company late Thursday lowered its Q3 revenue guidance to well below consensus expectations. The company also said it repurchased $250 million in shares during the quarter, leaving $750 million in its share repurchase program and a cash balance of more than $1 billion. Shares traded down 14% for the week and 50% below a June high.

On the IBD 50 list, Universal Display (OLED) flashed ahead nearly 5% at the open. The maker of organic light emitting diode chips used in high definition TV and computer screens is trading below a 55.93 buy point in a cup base. It triggered an automatic sell signal by diving more than 8% below that mark.

Hawaiian (HA) jumped more than 3% after reporting its total numbers of passengers rose 4.1% and its load factor crept up to 82.9% in the fourth quarter. The stock remains well below its 50-day moving average and is attempting to build the right side of a 22% deep consolidation.

Aircraft carrier mechanic Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) sailed ahead nearly 4%. Cowen & Co. upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Huntington is trading below a 136.55 buy point in a long cup-with-handle base.Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. Improved customer traffic helped drive CarMax (KMX) earnings and revenue to double-digit gains in the first quarter, sending shares soaring Friday.

The used-car retailer's revenue rose 13% to $3.75 billion, topping estimates of $3.59 billion and ending a three-quarter string of decelerating year-over-year growth. Earnings expanded 19% to 76 cents a share, beating analyst views for 67 cents and also ending a recent slowing trend.
Total used-car unit sales rose 9.8% and same-store used-car sales rose 3.4% from year-ago figures. Average selling prices rose 3.2% to $20,173. CarMax is also financing more of its car loans.
Shares of CarMax rose 14.4% to 51.81 in the stock market today. The stock is closing in on its record high of 53.08 set Dec. 19.
As part of its share buyback program, CarMax repurchased 3.8 million shares of common stock for $174.1 million.

"We had another great quarter, hitting an all-time record level of quarterly sales and earnings," President and CEO Tom Folliard said in a release. "The improvement was broad-based, with contributions from our retail and wholesale operations, as well as from CAF."
CarMax opened four stores in Q1.
Competitor Penske Auto Group (PAG) shares rose 2.6% intraday. Asbury Automotive Group (ABG) shares climbed 1.1%.

Small-town auto dealerLithia Motors (LAD) said this week that it will buy DCH Auto Group. Economic recovery might be the reason car-industry stocks have been on a roll lately. Two auto dealerships, CarMax (KMX) and AutoNation (AN), hit new highs Wednesday. CarMax, which operates at 131 locations around the country, rose 1.27 to close at 53.44. AutoNation, which owns and operates 270 new vehicle franchises in 15 states, rose 0.76 to close at 61.23. CarMax…

Used-car dealer CarMax (KMX) eyes a slight increase in sales and earnings when it reports fiscal first-quarter results this coming Friday, as the company tries to deal with increased competition in its niche.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the Richmond, Va.-based company to post EPS of 67 cents for the quarter, which ended in May. That's up from 64 cents the prior year. Sales are seen rising 9% to about $3.6 billion.

If those results hold up, it would mark the first time in seven quarters that CarMax failed to deliver a double-digit profit gain. It would also mark the second straight quarter of single-digit sales growth following a five-quarter run of double-digit gains.

During its fiscal fourth quarter, CarMax saw earnings rise 13% to 52 cents a share, missing views by a penny. Revenue climbed 8.8% to $3.08 billion, also slightly below consensus. Extreme winter weather in key Northeast and Southeast markets dampened results during Q4.

CarMax, the No. 1 car dealer by market cap, operates more than 120 used-car dealerships in 28 states. The company has benefited in recent years from a strong market for lower-cost used vehicles, as the sluggish economy convinced many consumers to spend less on big-ticket items.

"In the long run, CarMax's focus on the used-vehicle market and its aggressive store expansion strategy should help it outperform peers," analysts at Zacks Equity Research noted in a recent report. "The company also follows a strong capital deployment strategy via share buybacks."
At the same time, Zacks said, "We are concerned about the pressure on used-vehicle margins, high competition in the used-car market and high cash outflow of the company."
CarMax shares have been in a funk since establishing a record high of 53.08 in December. The stock currently trades near 44.
The company has an IBD Composite Rating of 50. It belongs to IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Automobile group, which ranks No. 54 out of 197 industries tracked.

Leaders in the group include Lithia Motors (LAD), which has a Composite Rating of 97; Asbury Automotive Group (ABG), with a Composite Rating of 96; Penske Automotive Group (PAG), with a Composite Rating of 95; and Group 1 Automotive (GPI), with a Composite Rating of 94.Used-car dealer CarMax (KMX) eyes a slight increase in sales and earnings when it reports fiscal first-quarter results this coming Friday, as the company tries to deal with increased competition in its niche.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the Richmond, Va.-based company to post EPS of 67 cents for the quarter, which ended in May. Wall Street rose for a second day Tuesday, leaving the major indexes just below record highs, as higher oil prices boosted energy stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%, the Nasdaq climbed 0.4% and the S&P 500 ended up 0.3%, with the latter two finishing just 1% below their all-time peaks. Volume was about 10% higher on both the NYSE and Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.

In the stock market today, oil producer Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) and driller Diamond Offshore (DO) each rose 6%, leading the S&P 500. Oil prices jumped more than 3% to just below $48 a barrel amid a strike by oil workers in Brazil and a port shutdown in Libya.

Noah Holdings (NOAH) led the IBD 50, jumping 10% in heavy volume as it climbs the right side of a deep base. The provider of wealth management services in China is due to report Q3 results Nov. 16. Profit for the period is seen rising 21% to 41 cents a share, which would be the biggest gain in four quarters.
Medical products stock Cambrex (CBM) rose more than 6% after a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report. It's also climbing the right side of a new base.

In post-session trading, luxury electric vehicle maker Tesla Motors (TSLA) rose sharply on a narrower-than-expected Q3 loss. The stock fell more than 2% during the regular session, ending 27% off its 52-week high.
Shares of real estate website Zillow (Z) was down about 5% after hours following its Q3 results.

Also after the close, Groupon (GPN) edged higher after its Q3 report. The provider of discounts from retailers also announced that COO Rich Williams will replace Eric Lefkofsky as CEO. Lefkofsky will become chairman.
LGI Homes (LGIH), Facebook (FB), Epam Systems (EPAM) and Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) are among companies reporting quarterly earnings Wednesday.

Economic reports due Wednesday include the Institute for Supply Management's index of service sector activity for October, ADP private-sector payrolls for November, crude oil inventories for the week ended Oct. 31 and the Mortgage Bankers Association's index of mortgage applications for the week ended Oct. 31.Wall Street rose for a second day Tuesday, leaving the major indexes just below record highs, as higher oil prices boosted energy stocks. Lithia Motors (LAD), AutoNation (AN) and other auto dealers rallied Tuesday on the most recent round of strong auto sales figures.

General Motors (GM) reported a 13% jump in May U.S. sales, its best showing in seven years. Ford (F), Chrysler, Toyota (TM) and others saw gains as consumers ventured out in May to shop for new cars after a long, hard winter across much of the nation.
Lithia rose about 2% to an all-time high in Tuesday afternoon trading on the stock market. After falling to a 53.57 low on Feb. 3, the dealer chain had risen about 48% in four months.

Lithia's stock is on the IBD 50 list of top-rated stocks, and it sports a best-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it has outperformed 99% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth in recent quarters.
Smaller Asbury Automotive Group (ABG), another IBD 50 stock, rose 3%.
Among other highly-rated dealers, AutoNation rose less than 1% Tuesday, also touching a new high. Its stock is up 16% year-to-date amid a succession of new highs. It has a 96 Composite Rating.
Penske Automotive Group (PAG) climbed 3% and Group 1 Automotive (GPI) was up 1%.

Sterne Agee raised its annual earnings estimates for both companies on May 2 after they reported strong quarterly earnings growth. Analyst Michael Ward said in a report at the time, "Our revisions reflect a better-than-expected financial performance, recently completed acquisitions and industry improvement in the U.K."
Both have a strong presence in the U.K. as well as the U.S.
CarMax (KMX) advanced 3%. The top U.S. auto dealer by market cap struggled early in the year in sync with the winter slowdown.

Did Penske Automotive Group (PAG) continue to operate in high gear in the first quarter? Investors will learn the answer when the auto retailer reports financial results on Thursday afternoon. If followers are right, Penske will stay on the fast track and deliver its fourth straight quarter of double-digit sales and earnings gain. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Penske…

CarMax (KMX) just missed third-quarter earnings forecasts as more customers borrowed from outside lenders, hurting financing income. The nation's top used car dealer chain by market capitalization earned 47 cents a share, up 15% from a year earlier but a penny below consensus. Revenue grew 13% to $2.94 billion in Q3, its weakest growth in more than a year, but…

CarMax (KMX) reported fourth-quarter revenue and profit gains, but both figures were slightly below analyst consensus. The company's stock price fell as much as 3% early Friday, leading the retail auto sector down.
Revenue rose 8.8% to $3.08 billion amid recovery in U.S. new-car sales. Used-car sales are also strong, as consumers nervous about weak economic growth continue to buy lower-cost used vehicles.

But revenue missed the $3.18 billion target. A series of heavy winter storms on the East Coast and in the Southeast likely chilled sales for the quarter. Sales at used-car outlets open at least a year rose 7%.
Earnings climbed 13% to 52 cents per share, missing forecasts by a penny a share.

The nation's largest retailer of used cars also announced a $1 billion share buyback program, which will expire on Dec. 31, 2015. It comes on top of the $800 million of repurchases previously authorized that remain in its previous plan.
CarMax bought back $306 million in stock during the fiscal year that ended Feb. 28.
Shares were down about 3% in more than four times usual volume in Friday-morning trading on the stock market today.

The company noted that during the quarter, it corrected accounting related to reserves set aside for its extended service plan (ESP) and guaranteed asset protection (GAP) warranty products. As a result, the company raised cancellation reserves, which reduced Q4 EPS by an estimated 8 cents a share.

CEO Tom Folliard said in a post-earnings statement, "We posted solid earnings growth in fiscal 2014, and we believe our continued geographic expansion and market-share growth will drive our success in the years to come."

The average price of CarMax used cars sold edged down less than 1% to $19,193 from $19,287 in the same quarter a year earlier. But, in line with rising tags for new cars throughout the industry, the average price of new CarMax vehicles rose 2% to $27,032.
Among other large auto retailers, AutoNation (AN), Penske Automotive (PAG), Lithia Motors (LAD) and Asbury Automotive Group (ABG) were all down less than 1% early Friday.

With big-cap names leading the way, stocks were higher as the noon hour approached Friday with the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 hitting all-time highs.
Volume swelled because of quadruple witching, the simultaneous quarterly expiration of single stock and index futures, and single stock and index options.
The Dow was the top performer among the major indexes, up 0.3%. The S&P 500 rose 0.2% and the Nasdaq gained 0.1%, just behind a 14-year high.
In the stock market today among Dow stocks, Merck (MRK) and Caterpillar (CAT) were up nearly 2%. DuPont (DD), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and ExxonMobil (XOM) were up more than 1%.
Among IBD 50 stocks, Irish drugmaker Shire (SHPG) was the top performer, up 17%. It rejected a buyout offer from AbbVie (ABBV), which was little changed after a volatile morning.

The worst performer was Emerge Energy Services (EMES), down 11%. It announced a secondary offering of 3.5 million shares at a 3.4% discount to Thursday's closing price. The company mines silica for hydraulic fracturing used in oil and gas drilling.

Auto dealer CarMax (KMX) looks to continue its recent streak of double-digit earnings and sales growth when it reports first-quarter results before the open on Friday. Shares of Group 1 Automotive (GPI) moved lower on the stock market today after the auto dealer beat quarterly revenue estimates but only met EPS views. The Houston-based company logged fourth-quarter earnings of $1.08 a share, up 9% from the prior year and in line with consensus estimates. The EPS increase was an improvement over Q3, when Group 1 reported…
The major averages ended mixed in quiet trade Thursday following weak economic data.

The Nasdaq slipped 0.3%, the S&P 500 eased 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%. Volume fell 21% on the NYSE and 18% on the Nasdaq compared to Wednesday, according to preliminary data.

Economic data released Thursday were disappointing. First-time jobless claims rose more than expected last week, while sales of existing homes fell more than forecast. But the market's losses were moderate.

In the stock market today, Oracle (ORCL) soared 6% in more than triple its average daily volume after a better-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock broke out of an irregular base, clearing a handle with a 35.85 buy point.

Lumber Liquidators (LL) was again among the best performers in the IBD 50. The flooring retailer rose 3% in heavy volume, notching its third gain in four sessions, as it tries to climb back to its 50-day line and repair the damage done by two big down days in the past month. Lumber is up 14% so far this week.

Winnebago Industries (WGO) was the IBD 50's biggest loser Thursday, diving 14% in massive volume and ending near its intraday low. Earnings rose 54% from the year-ago quarter, but sales of $222.7 million missed expectations. Shares plunged below the 50-day line.
Walgreen (WAG), Finish Line (FINL) and CarMax (KMX) are among companies scheduled to release quarterly earnings Friday.

Stocks turned mixed in late trading Tuesday as blue chips weakened. But the broad market continued to sport modest gains. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 rose 0.4% and 0.1% respectively. The Dow Jones industrial average turned fractionally lower, hurt by new entrant Visa (V). Turnover was again running mixed in the stock market today. Nasdaq trade was again tracking…

Stocks pushed to fresh session highs late Tuesday, extending a rebound after Monday's tumble. The Nasdaq led with a 0.8% gain, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.5%. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.4%. Volume was tracking lower on both major exchanges compared with the same time Monday.
Earlier in the stock market today, Greece asked for a new bailout as a midnight deadline for a payment to the International Monetary Fund loomed.

Leading stocks up in heavy trade were few, but Boot Barn Holdings (BOOT) stepped up 6% to a new high on positive actions from analysts. B. Riley started coverage of the retailer with a buy recommendation and placed a price target at 35. Jefferies lifted the stock's price target to 40 from 30.

Taser International (TASR) rallied 5% and retook its 50-day line in active trading. The stock fell more than 8% below a 35.10 buy point from a flat base Monday, triggering a sell signal. Earlier Tuesday, the company announced it won an order for body cameras from the Fresno, Calif., police department.

Synaptics (SYNA) rose 2%, putting it on pace to snap a seven-session slide. The stock recently wiped out a near-19% gain from a breakout past an 86.36 buy point, marking a sell signal. This month, Synaptics sold off on reports that Apple (AAPL) is making its own touch controller/display driver (TDDI) chip for future iPhones.

On the downside, Skechers (SKX) was off its session low, but still down nearly 2% in fast trade. The stock is further cooling off after it ended a 10-week win streak and is getting closer to testing its 10-week line. The stock surged almost 84% from a breakout past a 62.44 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Stocks pushed to fresh session highs late Tuesday, extending a rebound after Monday's tumble. The retail giant was off its session low, but still down more than 1%. Bloomberg reported that the world's largest retailer was cutting orders as inventory piled up. But…

Car retailers' stocks are cruising into new high ground, even though Tuesday's U.S. retail sales report showed a drop in auto sales last month. Reflecting the higher overall auto-sales trend, Retail/Wholesale-Automotive was one of the groups hitting a 52-week intraday high, among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Meanwhile, shares of fellow auto dealer Group 1 Automotive (GPI) sagged 5% after it fell well short of Q3 profit views. A robust market for auto sales should help used car dealer CarMax (KMX) continue its run of double-digit financial growth when it reports fiscal second-quarter results before the open Tuesday. The stock market closed higher Thursday, although indexes pared gains.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.8% while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%.
Volume rose on the NYSE, but fell on the Nasdaq, according to early figures. Advancing stocks led decliners by 7-to-5 on the Nasdaq, but winners barely edged out losers on the NYSE.
Computer, trucking and financials ranked among the day's top performing sectors. Retail, metals and energy stocks lagged.
A weak forecast sent a chill through homebuilding stocks in the stock market today.

Meritage Homes (MTH) cut its forecast for 2015 earnings, citing rising labor costs, delays in closings and slower-than-expected business in the company's newer markets in the Southeast. The stock fell 9% in heavy trading, to the lowest level since early February.

"There are shortages of skilled labor in many markets as subcontractors struggle to catch up with the increased demand of a continued recovery in homebuilding," said Chairman and CEO Steven J. Hilton. Competition for labor is raising costs and lengthening construction times, his statement added. Bad weather in parts of Texas and Colorado further hurt the company.
The homebuilders' industry group, which has been a market leader, was one of the worst 20 groups Thursday out of 197 that IBD tracks.

One of the day's biggest losers was Lululemon Athletica (LULU), which plunged 16% after the yoga-styled apparel chain guided Q3 and full-year earnings below expectations. Shares fell to the lowest level since December.
Google (GOOGL) rose 1% and shares continued to rise from support at the 50-day moving average. But volume in Google was light.
After the close, shares of action sports retailer Zumiez (ZUMZ) slid after the company announced quarterly results. The stock closed regular trading near a 52-week low.

Several stocks that had found support in pullbacks to the 50-day moving average have gone on to hit new highs. Yandex (YNDX), for example, climbed 1.69 to 34.67 in more than double its average volume. The Russian Internet company had pulled back to its 50-day line last week. It rebounded and with Thursday's 5% rally became extended from its buy…

How many of your neighbors are suddenly driving new cars? Auto sales are rebounding as cautious Americans who held onto their cars through the economic downturn are now trading up to newer vehicles. Sales of new cars rose 17% in August, reaching an annualized rate of 16.09 million — not a record, but the fastest pace since December 2007. AutoNation[ticker…

Stocks weakened and turned mixed in late trading Friday. But they were still on track to end higher for the week. The Nasdaq trimmed a 0.5% gain to 0.1%. The S&P 500 slipped 0.2% after being up nearly 0.3%. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 0.4%, hurt by Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM). Both reported lackluster quarterly results earlier in the stock market today. Volume was tracking lower on both major exchanges compared with the same time Thursday.

In leading stocks, Envision Healthcare (EVHC) gapped up and surged 11% to a new high in reaction to late Thursday's better-than-expected earnings and news of an acquisition. The medical service provider posted adjusted earnings of 37 cents a share, up 32% from a year ago. The company also announced it would buy ambulance operator Rural/Metro for $620 million in cash. Envision is now 12% past a 40.37 buy point from a cup base cleared in late June.

HFF (HF) was off its session high, but still up 6% after late Thursday's upbeat Q2 results. The provider of commercial real estate service reported Q2 earnings of 55 cents a share, up 67% from a year ago. Sales climbed 32% to $125 million. Views were for 44 cents a share on sales of $117.56 million. HFF recently regained a 42.63 buy point from a flat base and is now extended.

On the downside, Outerwall (OUTR) gapped below its 50-day line and dived 13% on late Thursday's disappointing Q2 sales. The operator of Redbox and Coinstar kiosk posted $545.4 million in revenue vs. views of $561.1 million. Its earnings, which beat expectations, climbed 44% to $2.19 a share. The stock fell more than 8% below a 78.04 buy point from a cup base, marking a sell signal.

Taser International (TASR) was off its session low, but still down 3% in fast trade. The stock fell nearly 7% at Friday's low, but found support near its 200-day line. Taser had already tumbled 11% Thursday as a weak outlook trumped better-than-expected Q2 results.Stocks weakened and turned mixed in late trading Friday. The recent run of strong financial results by publicly traded car dealers continued Thursday as AutoNation (AN) met second-quarter earnings views and beat sales expectations. The nation's biggest auto dealer group by revenue benefited from strong performances across all of its business lines, including sales of new and used vehicles, parts and service, and finance and insurance. AutoNation management also…

June was one of the best months for automakers since the recession and proved to be a good month for car dealerships. AutoNation (AN) reported a 10% rise in June sales on Wednesday as demand for domestic vehicles rose.

The dealership operator said new-vehicle sales rose 10% to 25,162 last month and same-store new-vehicle sales jumped 5% to 24,107. Same-stores sales are an important measurement that takes out the effects of stores opening or closing.
AutoNation shares fell 1.5% on the stock market today. Rival auto dealers CarMax (KMX) and Lithia Motors (LAD) rose 0.5% and dipped 0.3%, respectively.
AutoNation said domestic sales soared 15% to 8,130 vs. June 2012 and international sales were up 8% to 12,460. Premium luxury sales were also up 8% to 4,572.

On Tuesday, Ford Motor (F) reported a 13% jump in June sales to 103,860 small cars and trucks. Trucks soared 24% to their best level since 2005. General Motors (GM) sales rose 6% year-over-year to 264,843 vehicles, the highest since September 2008. Silverado sales surged 29%; Sierra sales jumped 33%. Chrysler's U.S. sales rose 8% last month to 156,686 vehicles, in line with expectations.
The Retail/Wholesale-Automobile group is ranked No. 123 out of the 197 industries IBD covers.

NYSE indexes recovered off session lows and ended moderately higher Friday. The Nasdaq fell 0.2% after being down by as much as 1.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 gained 0.3%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in higher than Thursday amid options expirations. For the week, the S&P 500 gave up 2.1%, the Nasdaq…
Stocks set sail with mild gains in massive trade early Friday as the market tried to gather its wits after Thursday's sell-off.
The S&P 500 bobbed 0.5% higher. The Dow Jones industrial average tacked on 0.3% while the Nasdaq inched up a fraction.
Quadruple witching options expirations amplified volume in the stock market today, with trade soaring 470% on the NYSE and up more than 300% on the Nasdaq compared with Thursday morning's activity.

In stocks, auto dealership chain CarMax (KMX) popped 5% at the open after reporting stronger-than-expected first-quarter results. Earnings and revenue topped analyst expectations, and the company repurchased 2.9 million shares during the quarter. The stock pulled back from a May 16 high for a quiet test of the 50-day moving average, then fell through that line in heavy trade Thursday. Friday's move lifted shares back above the 50-day moving average, at least temporarily as the stock gave back some ground.

Oracle (ORCL) swooned 9% at the open, diving through its 200-day moving average in heavy trade. The enterprise software maker reported late Thursday its fiscal Q4 earnings met views, but revenue stopped short of analysts' forecasts. It was the second straight quarterly sales miss.

The stock had crept higher after selling off on its Q3 sales and earnings miss. It fell through the 50-day average in heavy trade Thursday. Friday's slip drove shares to their lowest mark since November.
Among leaders, drugmakers led a mild rebound among IBD 50 stocks. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) gained 2%.
Both Michael Kors (KORS) and Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) gave up pre-market gains of more than 4% and posted fractional losses in opening trade.

Lumber Liquidators (LL) dropped 2% in a second day of heavy trade. Stocks opened lower in hushed trade Monday ahead of the start of third-quarter earnings seasons and on a quiet, Columbus Day economic calendar.
The Nasdaq posted a 0.4% loss. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each trimmed 0.3%. Volume whispered 49% lower on the Nasdaq and was off 23% on the NYSE compared with Friday.

In stocks, Netflix (NFLX) continued to rebound, adding 8% in strong trade. The movie rental service bounced 22% last week, retaking its 10-week moving average. But it remains well below its 40-week moving average, and 77% below its July 2011 high.

Carmax (KMX) bolted 11% in massive trade. A report from ITG Research put the used-auto dealership chain's revenues up 17% and said the company was likely to top analysts' consensus estimate when it reports its fiscal third-quarter in December.

Among leading stocks, Panera Bread (PNRA) dropped 3% in opening trade. The stock has been trading tightly since clearing a flat base in mid-September. But it dropped 2% Friday after a downgrade, to market perform from outperform, from RBC Capital Markets.

Overseas, major French and German indexes pared losses, but remained sharply lower in afternoon trade. Stocks launched higher in heavy trade Friday, with the Dow and S&P 500 quickly stepping ahead to new highs.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.5%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3%.

Options expirations sent volume soaring compared with Thursday's trade. The stock market today also received an early boost from a sharp upward revision to the Commerce Department's third-quarter GDP growth estimate.
Nike (NKE) slipped, Walgreen (WAG) rose 1% each after reporting quarterly results.
IBD 50 stocks were widely mixed, with about half the list up.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) spiked 8% in heavy trade after announcing late Thursday it would acquire Italian drugmaker Gentium (GENT) in a deal valued near $1 billion. The gain sent Jazz to a new high after a quick pullback stopped short of the 10-week line. Gentium shares rose 3%.

Chip designer Ambarella (AMBA) opened to a 9% gain, surging on news that it would demonstrate a new wearable camera jointly developed with Google (GOOG) during the January Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. The heavy-volume move punched shares above a 25.79 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern for Ambarella.

The used-car dealership chain said Q3 EPS rose 14% to 41 cents, beating analyst views by 2 cents. Revenue jumped 15% to $2.6 billion, beating estimates of $2.47 billion. AutoNation shares continued to fall Friday as Deutsche Bank maintained a sell rating on the auto dealer operators following its Thursday earnings miss.
Deutsche Bank raised its price target to $27 from $25, but that's still well below current levels.

The company's stock price fell 4.75% to 45.76 Thursday after it logged third-quarter earnings of 66 cents a share. That was up 38% from the prior year, but a penny below Wall Street views. Revenue rose 12% to $3.93 billion, slightly below the $3.95 billion analysts expected.
AutoNation shares fell about 2% in early Friday trading.

Shares of AutoNation (AN) had been trending higher for the last four months, reaching an all-time high of 48.56 on Oct. 19. The company has logged four straight quarters of double-digit sales and earnings growth.
Other auto dealers took a hit on earnings as well on Thursday. Shares of Group 1 (GPI) fell 2.2% on Thursday, while shares of Lithia Motors (LAD) declined 7.4%.

In early Friday trading , Group 1 shares edged lower while Lithia rose more than 1%. Penske Automotive Group (PAG), which operates 320 auto dealerships, topped third-quarter earnings and sales estimates, but shares tumbled 10% in midday trading Friday on falling profit margins.

The No. 2 U.S. car dealership group said Q2 earnings increased 20% to 60 cents per share, beating analyst estimates by 3 cents. Sales climbed 15% to $3.4 billion, also above forecasts of $3.3 billion.
But the average gross profit per vehicle narrowed 80 basis points to 7.7%, while profit margins on used cars were down 20 basis points to 7.3%.
"While new and used unit sales were strong, we experienced pricing pressure in our markets, especially when compared to the third quarter last year," Chairman Roger Penske said.

Penske said revenue from dealerships open at least a year rose 11.7%. Total U.S. vehicle sales rose 21% and international sales jumped 29%. New vehicle sales, which account for about 50% of Penske's revenue, were up 26%. Used vehicle sales rose 20%.
Sales increased, but the average price per new vehicle fell 4% to $36,497 and used car prices fell 5% to $24,982 per vehicle.
The average gross profit per vehicle narrowed 80 basis points to 7.7%. Margins on used cars were down 20 basis points to 7.3%.
Shares of Penske's largest rivals, Carmax (KMX) and AutoNation (AN), slipped less than 1% each in midday trading Friday.
The Retail/Wholesale-Automotive group is ranked No. 18 out of Investor's Business Daily's 197 industry groups.

Asbury Automotive Group (ABG) leads the group with a top Composite Rating of 99. IBD's Composite Rating measures stocks in five areas, with extra weight on earnings and stock price strength. Lithia Motors (LAD) also has a Composite Rating of 99. Stocks slunk lower in strong trade Tuesday, as investors reacted to a wave of mixed earnings and economic data.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.5%, the S&P 500 0.3% and the Nasdaq 0.1%. Volume rose 34% on the Nasdaq and 22% on the NYSE compared with Monday's early action.

The stock market today received an early boost from the Case-Shiller 20-City home price index, which jumped 9.3% for February, well above January's 8.1% increase and better than expectations for a 9% gain.

That was offset by a contraction in Midwest manufacturing activity in April, sending the Chicago Purchasing Managers Index to 49, its worst reading in more than three years. Analysts had expected the index to hold steady at 52.4.

Consumer confidence spiked this month, however, sending the Conference Board's initial results from its April consumer confidence survey to 68.1. That was far above March's 59.7 result, above forecasts for 62 and the survey's best reading since November.

In stocks, Nuance Communications (NUAN) collapsed 18% in furious trade after its first-quarter results missed expectations by a wide margin. The maker of speech-recognition software reported earnings slipped 21%, vs. forecasts for a 6% decline. Revenue rose 16%, below views for a 24% increase. Management cited a "combination of execution issues and external factors."
The stock has been correcting since February.
Avon Products (AVP) rose 7% in heavy trading. The stock has become extended from a breakout past a 20.98 buy point.

The New York-based network marketer of cosmetics reported adjusted first-quarter earnings up 160%, well above views. Revenue slipped 4%, slightly more than expected. Adjusted gross margin improved 160 basis points to 62.5%.
CarMax (KMX) led the IBD 50 with a 3% gain. That bumped the used car dealer to a new high after its second rebound from 10-week support following an early March breakout.

Managed care insurer Aetna (AET) gained more than 2% after itsfirst-quarter report topped analyst forecasts. The report showed impact from rising health care costs and acquisition expenses. But earnings per share easily beat estimates. A 7% gain in operating revenue fell short of expectations, but management raised its full-year earnings guidance to the high-end of analyst estimates.
The stock is just below its December 2007 record and has been in a steady uptrend since clearing a cup-with-handle base.

Following her accountant's advice to lease a car for her business, attorney and mother-of-two Liz Chatham drove off the Chapman BMW lot in Phoenix, Ariz., in a sparkling white 2011 BMW 328i in late February. Eager to clear out last year's inventory, the dealership knocked $10,000 off the original price. And it gave Chatham a 0.09% interest rate on the…

The major indexes lost ground in early trade Wednesday, despite a sharper-than-expected drop in weekly jobless claims.The Nasdaq and Dow fell 0.5% each, the S&P 500 shed 0.4% and the NYSE composite lost 0.3%. Volume rose 1% on the NYSE and fell 24% on the Nasdaq vs. the same period Tuesday.Las Vegas Sands (LVS) skidded 4% in fast trade. The casino and resort operator rocketed from the start of the year to Friday's multiyear high. The stock has since reversed and sits 7% off that peak.Lam Research (LRCX) also gave up 4% in rapid turnover. The maker of etching and cleaning systems used in the chipmaking process is down for the second straight day after Goldman Sachs removed Lam from its conviction buy list.On the upside, CarMax (KMX) advanced 3% in above-average volume. The used car superstore operator broke out of a three-weeks-tight pattern on Oct. 29 and has notched new highs since then. The stock sports a 93 Relative Price Strength Rating and an A+ Accumulation/Distribution Rating.An earlier report showed first-time unemployment claims falling by 24,000 to 435,000 last week. Economists had expected a much smaller drop, to 450,000.

Stocks remained in the red but off their session lows in late-afternoon trade Wednesday.The Nasdaq shed 1.6%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 lost 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. Turnover continued to track higher on the Nasdaq but lower on the NYSE.Among S&P 100 stocks, Walgreen (WAG) fell 2% in big trade and dropped below its 50-day moving average, but it had been down as much as 8%. The drugstore chain reported fiscal first-quarter earnings that missed forecasts. Walgreen is trading about 27% below its June peak, as well as under its 200-day moving average. It has a weak IBD Composite Rating of 38, out of a highest-possible grade of 99.CarMax (KMX) slid 7% in fast turnover, as it also posted quarterly earnings that missed estimates. The used-car seller tumbled below its 50-day and 200-day lines. CarMax, which boasts a solid 93 Composite Rating, is trading 21% below its February peak as it continues to consolidate.Rackspace Hosting (RAX) dropped 4% in heavy volume. The cloud-computing stock, which has a strong Composite Rating of 97, finished Tuesday near a 45.56 handle buy point, but it's now backed off as it keeps working on its latest base. Tech stocks are struggling today following Oracle's (ORCL) earnings miss late Tuesday. Oracle is down 13%.

Stocks were down moderately Tuesday afternoon after two Federal Reserve policymakers suggested the central bank was leaning toward withdrawing stimulus soon. The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3% and the Nasdaq 0.2%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking more than 10% higher than Monday's pace. Dallas Fed President Richard Fisher told CNBC that the market should…
Stocks continued to show mostly moderate losses near the end of Monday's session.

The Nasdaq dropped 0.8%, weighed down by Apple (AAPL). The S&P 500 lost 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.2%. Volume was down sharply across the board amid little economic news. The Treasury market is closed for the Columbus Day holiday.

On the upside, PetSmart (PETM) gained 3% in heavy volume, helped by an upbeat research note from Credit Suisse. The specialty retailer, often featured in IBD's Income Investor column, is lifting off its 10-week moving average after hugging that support level for about three weeks.

CarMax (KMX) surged 9% in huge trade, as ITG Research said sales growth is accelerating for the used car retailer. The stock has jumped back above its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. But it sports a weak IBD Composite Rating of 49 out of a best-possible 99, hurt by a lack of EPS growth in the past two quarters.

GNC Holdings (GNC) climbed 2% in strong volume. The specialty retailer is trying to break out past a 41.04 handle buy point. It lifted above that level, but is now back below it. GNC is No. 32 in the latest IBD 50 lineup.

Apple slumped 2% in big turnover, falling further below its 50-day moving average. The stock, No. 18 in the latest IBD 50 lineup, is now just 4% above its recent handle buy point at 619.97, after being up as much as 14% from that level. Recent reports about Apple have focused on a strike at Foxconn, a Chinese company that manufactures the iPhone.

E-commerce giant eBay (EBAY) dropped 2% in roughly average turnover, falling to support near its 10-week moving average. Stocks opened lower Wednesday, but turned narrowly mixed ahead of this afternoon's news from the Federal Reserve.
The NYSE composite and S&P were fractionally higher. But the Nasdaq fell 0.2%, dragged down by software and chip stocks. Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board.

NuVasive (NUVA) gapped down and lost nearly 4% after announcing a note offering. Late Tuesday, the medical products maker said it intends to offer $325 million in convertible notes. Proceeds will be for general corporate uses, as well as for repurchasing a previous note offering.

CarMax (KMX) gapped above its 50-day and 200-day moving average, gaining 8%. Before the open, the used car retailer delivered Q1 earnings of 55 cents a share. That's up 25% from a year ago and 8 cents above expectations. Sales grew 18% to nearly $2.68 billion vs. views of $2.52 billion. CarMax may be forming an odd-shaped double bottom.

HealthSpring (HS) rose 3% to an all-time high in fast trade. That puts it 5% past a 45.21 buy point from a flat base it cleared on Tuesday. The managed health care firm has delivered accelerating sales growth in recent quarters.
Some of Tuesday's other breakouts, such as Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH), made slight gains in early trading.
