The major indexes remained little changed in early afternoon action, as volume continued to track lower across the board.The Nasdaq composite, NYSE composite and S&P 500 all were just barely in positive territory, holding on to gains of less than 0.1%.On the upside, Ultratech (UTEK) climbed 7% in huge trade, as it lifted off its 10-week moving average. The producer of chipmaking gear has pulled back to its 10-week line twice since a breakout in December. Ultratech has a sterling IBD Composite Rating of 98, but it is somewhat thinly traded.On the downside, Tal International (TAL) shed 4% in heavy turnover. The provider of freight containers moved above a 37.33 buy point from a square-box base on Wednesday. Tal is now back below that level. The stock has a 98 Composite Rating.CarMax (KMX) was down 7% in big volume, falling under its 10-week moving average. The used-car retailer reported Q4 EPS and revenue that beat the Street's forecasts, but its gross margin slid to 14.2% from 14.5% a year ago. CarMax has a Composite Rating of 78, which is lower than normally seen in leading stocks. The stock had been consolidating along its 10-week line.Two breakouts today showed strong volume earlier, but their trading has tailed off. Volume in Gardner Denver (GDI) is running about 20% above average, while  Sensata's (ST) volume is now tracking below average.

The stock market had a muted reaction to the Fed's latest policy statement, holding to small gains.The major indexes made modest progress after the 12:30 p.m. ET announcement. The S&P 500, Nasdaq and NYSE composite were up less than 0.1%. But small caps were stronger, with the Russell 2000 adding 0.3%. Volume remained lower across the board.As expected, the Federal Reserve's policymaking body left its interest-rate target at 0% to 0.25%. The Fed noted that the pace of economic recovery was going slower than it had expected. It also said a rise in inflation should be temporary.The market now awaits a press conference by Chairman Ben Bernanke.Among leading stocks, Avago Technologies  (AVGO) surged 4%. The stock is forming a base-on-base pattern with a potential buy point at 36.28. The base would be a late-stage pattern, and so far has little accumulation.Auto stocks were among the best performing Wednesday. CarMax Group (KMX) beat earnings expectations, citing a strong used-car market. CarMax is forming the right side of an odd double bottom.Penske Automotive Group (PAG) and  AutoNation (AN) also rose in heavy trading. Both stocks also are forming the right side of bases.The energy, metals and transportation sectors also were showing strength.

The major indexes continued to trade higher across the board Tuesday, as the market digested some earnings news and looked ahead to more after the close.The NYSE composite picked up 0.7%, the Nasdaq 0.6%, the S&P 500 and Dow 0.4% each. Volume remained slightly lower on the NYSE and higher on the Nasdaq vs. the same period Monday.Nike (NKE) rose 1% in brisk turnover. The athletic shoe and apparel giant is slated to report quarterly earnings results after today's close. The stock is already at all-time highs, having found support at its 50-day moving average on Nov. 16. Earnings growth has accelerated in each of the past three quarters.Red Hat (RHT) is also slated to release quarterly results after the close. The maker of open source enterprise operating systems is projected to earn 20 cents a share on $227 million in revenue for fiscal Q3. Shares of Red Hat were nearly unchanged.On the downside, CarMax (KMX) dived 7% in huge volume. The used car retailer posted third-quarter earnings results that topped views. But the company's gross profit per vehicle sold fell short of estimates. CarMax's stock did find support at its 50-day line and has pared some of its earlier, even bigger losses.

Apparel makers have shined throughout the quarter as shoppers have flocked to the malls to get the lasted fashions. Ascena Retail (ASNA) is expected to continue the trend when it reports earnings Wednesday.
Analysts are expecting the operator of Dress Barn and Maurices clothing stores to post a 21% jump in fourth-quarter earnings to 29 cents a share. Sales are seen rising 7.4% to $779.66 million.
Women's fashion is rebounding after a long perioud of sluggish sales following the recession.
"Women's wear started gaining momentum in the last quarter," said Marshal Cohen, chief retail analyst at NPD Group. "Without that momentum it would have been a whole different market."
Cohen is expecting women's wear sales to continue growing in the next six months.
The Retail-Apparel, Accessories and Shoes group is ranked No. 8 out of Investor's Business Daily's 197 industry groups.
Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) will also report earnings Wednesday. The home goods retailer is expected to report a 9.7% rise in Q2 EPS to $1.02. Analyst see sales increasing 9% to $2.52 billion.
On Thursday, Pier One (PIR) reported earnings in line with estimates and raised its full year EPS outlook.
Overall retail sales rose 0.9% in August on gasoline and auto sales, according to a report by the Commerce Department on Friday.
AutoZone (AZO), an auto parts store operator, will announce earnings Wednesday. Analysts are expecting a 17% climb in Q4 EPS to $8.41. Sales are seen rising 6% to $2.8 billion.

Used car dealership Carmax (KMX) is slated to report second-quarter earnings Thursday. Analysts expect its EPS to rise 4% to 51 cents. Despite the losses, the indexes continued to hold above key levels. The Nasdaq remains above the 3000 psychological level, as well as its converged 50-day and 200-day moving averages. The S&P…

Stocks turned moderately positive Thursday after showing mixed action. The S&P 500 rose 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.3% and the Nasdaq gained 0.2%. Volume continued to track down from Wednesday's levels across the board. CBS (CBS) rose 3% in heavy turnover, clearing a 36.73 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern. The media giant has an OK grade…
Stocks mustered gains in lackluster trading Thursday amid mixed economic data and uncertainties from the fiscal cliff.
The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 rose 0.5% each. The Nasdaq gained 0.2%. Volume fell across the board, according to early data.
After the close, Red Hat (RHT), Tibco Software (TIBX) and Nike (NKE) were active in extended trading.
Software maker Red Hat jumped 7% after it reported fiscal Q3 earnings that matched views and sales that beat views. Red Hat also announced an acquisition.
Tibco rose in late trading after its fiscal Q4 profit came in above estimates. But revenue slightly missed expectations.
Athletic apparel giant Nike advanced in extended trading after it posted fiscal Q2 results above views.

In the regular session, CarMax (KMX) gapped up and closed up 9% in fast trade after reporting fiscal third-quarter results that exceeded Wall Street's estimates. The stock is making its first test of the 10-week line since clearing a cup-with-handle base Oct. 13. CarMax has a respectable IBD Composite Rating of 87 out of a best-possible 99, but its EPS Rating is a weak 69.
Ashland (ASH) rallied 3% to an all-time high in heavy trading. The lift puts it 3% past a 78.37 buy point from a cup base cleared Dec. 12.

Retailer Bed Bath & Beyond's lackluster outlook probably torpedoed SodaStream (SODA), which fell 3% in big volume. The maker of home soda machines briefly undercut its recent 43.10 handle buy point, then climbed back above that key level. Bed Bath & Beyond stores provide one of SodaStream's major sales channels.

Accenture (ACN) ended well off its session low, losing just 2% and closing above its 50-day moving average. The consulting firm was down as much as 6% in reaction to its fiscal Q1 results, released late Wednesday. Accenture earnings rose 10% in the latest quarter to $1.06, or a penny above views. But sales rose 2% to $7.2 billion, missing views for $7.31 billion. The company also guided Q4 revenue a bit shy of expectations.

The Commerce Department revised its estimate for third-quarter U.S. GDP growth to 3.1%, up from its prior estimate of 2.7% and above expectations for 2.8%. The latest figures for existing-home sales and Philadelphia-region manufacturing showed gains and beat forecasts. But initial weekly jobless claims were higher than expected.
In the fiscal-cliff negotiations, the House is expected to vote on Speaker John Boehner's "Plan B" Thursday evening.

The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were under selling pressure Friday, but selling was muted in the Nasdaq.

Indexes were near session lows with a little more than one hour left in the session. The Dow lost 0.8%; the S&P 500 fell 0.6% and the Nasdaq eased 0.2%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume tracking higher than Thursday; more so on the NYSE. Options expired today, which resulted in higher volume across the board.

In the stock market today, Fleetmatics Group (FLTX) bounced back 2% after Thursday's shellacking. Shares cratered 16% after a Seeking Alpha article raised questions about the company's accounting practices. The Ireland-based developer of mobile fleet management software went public in October and nearly tripled from its offering price of $17. Shares were recently trading around 39.

Meanwhile, two more IPOs hit the ground running Friday. FireEye (FEYE) priced at $20 a share and opened at 40.30. Shares were recently trading around 39. And Rocket Fuel (FUEL) priced at $29 and opened at 59.95. Shares recently exchanged hands around 55.

Inside the IBD 50, Generac Holdings (GNRC) continued work on the right side of a shallow, cup-shaped base. Shares rose 2%. The potential buy point is 44.40, but keep in mind that Generac's current structure is fourth-stage base after a big price move already. The company makes generators for residential and commercial markets.
Elsewhere, Spirit Airlines (SAVE) added 1%. The stock went public in May 2011 at $12. It's working on the right side of a cup-shaped base but it's also a fourth-stage structure.

On the downside, Yandex (YNDX) slumped 5% after a nice accumulation phase in recent days. The Russian search firm surged to an all-time high Thursday in heavy volume, but it's extended after a cup-with-handle breakout in July and a bounce off its 10-week moving average during the week ended Sept. 6.
Next week is fairly quiet on the earnings docket, but here's a look at some names scheduled to report.
Tuesday: Lennar (LEN), KB Home (KBH) and CarMax (KMX).
Wednesday: Bed, Bath and Beyond (BBBY).

The U.S. auto industry was nearly wrecked during the last recession. New-car sales plunged to 10.4 million in 2009 from 16.2 million in 2007. It nearly killed General Motors (GM) and Chrysler Group, and shuttered about 20% of auto retail dealerships. It was a challenging period for DealerTrack (TRAK), which provides auto loan services and inventory management solutions for dealerships,…

Gaming, auto and homebuilder companies led the list of stocks hitting new highs Thursday. U.S.-listed Japanese stocks hit new highs amid expectations that profits will rise as the yen weakens. Nippon Telegraph & Telephone (NTT), Toyota Motor (TM) and Honda Motor (HMC) all posted modest gains, with Honda climbing in strong volume ahead of its fourth-quarter results Friday. The Bank…

U.S. retail sales fell short of growth projections in August as weakness in apparel and sporting goods offset gains in cars and other expensive items. According to data released this morning from the Commerce Department, retail sales rose 0.2% last month vs. July. That was below the 0.5% gain expected by most analysts and represented the smallest increase since April.…

Stocks extended gains and were near session highs in early afternoon trading Friday.The Nasdaq rallied 0.7% and poked above the 2400 level, which has acted as resistance in recent sessions. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 climbed 0.7% each. The Dow rose 0.6%, crossing the 11,000 level for the first time since early May. Turnover was again tracking mixed, with the Nasdaq's higher and the NYSE's lower.Farm equipment makers also rallied on news that the U.S. Department of Agriculture had cut its corn crop estimate.Deere & Co. (DE) gapped up and rose 6% to a two-year high, putting shares 3% past a buy range up to 73.80 after a rebound off the 50-day moving average.Two other farm equipment companies, Lindsay (LNN) and CNH Global (CNH), jumped 8% each in heavy volume.Elsewhere, Lululemon Athletica (LULU) rallied 6% in fast action. The stock is 10% past a 43.47 buy point that it first crossed in mid-September. At the midpoint of Friday's session, Lululemon had already traded 130% of its average daily volume. The yoga apparel retailer has delivered three straight quarters of triple-digit profit growth.CarMax (KMX) revved up 5% to an all-time high. The stock has gained 11% since clearing a 26.60 buy point from a cup base Sept. 23. Last month, the used-car retailer beat views with a 4% increase in Q2 earnings. Analysts see its full-year earnings rising 26%. The stock's EPS Rank, though, is only 70, which means 30% of the market is growing earnings faster.Gold bounced back after reversing from an all-time high Thursday. The December contract climbed $10.80 to $1,345.80 an ounce.

Stocks improved slightly and turned mixed in afternoon trading Thursday.The Dow fell 0.4%, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 slipped 0.2% each. But the NYSE composite eked out a 0.1% gain. Volume was tracking slightly higher on both exchanges.AutoNation (AN) gapped down, slumped 6% and breached its 50-day moving average. Before the open, the nation's biggest vehicle retailer reported Q3 earnings of 39 cents a share, up 8%, but 3 cents below views. Sales grew 13%, beating views.Group mate CarMax (KMX) reversed earlier gains and slipped 1%.Solutia (SOA) reversed morning gains and fell 3% in fast trade. Late Wednesday, the chemical maker beat views with a 13.5% rise in Q3 earnings and a 17% increase in sales. The company expects full-year revenue and profit to be at the high end of its prior outlook. Its previous guidance for sales was $480 million to $500 million and $1.40 to $1.50 for earnings.On the upside, Las Vegas Sands (LVS) gapped up and surged 8% in heavy volume. Late Wednesday, the company crushed views with a 1,033% explosion in Q3 earnings and a 67% gain in sales. Results were boosted by strength at its Macau and Singapore casinos.Akamai Technologies (AKAM) pulled well off session highs, but was still up 2% in heavy trading. Shares were up more than 6% at session peak. After Wednesday's close, the provider of application delivery services reported lower Q3 earnings, but topped views.Elsewhere, gold settled at $1,342.70 an ounce, up $20.10. Gold producers were mostly higher.

The new- and used-car chain sputtered in the first quarter, posting profit and sales that missed analysts' estimates, as more people visited its stores, but fewer of them bought vehicles. CarMax (KMX) shares fell as much as 8% early when the company failed to respond to pressure from larger rival AutoNation (AN) and others, as earlier robust auto sales faltered…

Are Americans going back to the dealership — and are they buying new or used cars? Investors will have a better answer to those questions after CarMax (KMX) announces first-quarter earnings Thursday before the market opens.

Automakers are struggling as the average age of cars on the road in the U.S. is at an all-time high of 10.8 years amid ongoing consumer belt-tightening, according to R.L. Polk & Co., an automotive market research firm.

Ford's (F) Q1 EPS fell 37%, its sales dipped 2% and the company said sales in April were "challenging." The automaker's shares rose 0.9% Wednesday. General Motors (GM) also saw a decline in sales in its most recent quarterly report. Its shares slipped 1.2% Wednesday.

Analysts are expecting CarMax, the largest operator of used-car dealerships in the U.S., to report a 3.6% year-over-year drop in Q1 earnings to 53 cents per share. Sales are expected to climb 4.8% to $2.8 billion. It also operates a few new-car franchises at its superstores.

During the fourth quarter, CarMax reported EPS and sales above Wall Street expectations, but it was the fifth straight quarter of contracting profit margins, and that sent shares down nearly 2% the day of that report.
CarMax currently operates 111 used-car superstores across the U.S.
The Retail/Wholesale-Automobile group is ranked No. 153 out of Investor's Business Daily's 197 industry groups.
Group leader Lithia Motors (LAD), which sells new and used cars, raised its Q1 dividend after posting an 82% jump in EPS in May. Shares fell 1.8% Wednesday.

Top group members include America's Car-Mart (CRMT), Penske Automotive (PAG) and Group I Automotive (GPI).Are Americans going back to the dealership — and are they buying new or used cars? CarMax (KMX) topped analyst profit expectations in the fourth quarter as used car sales rose for the first time in three quarters. But shares of the retail chain for new and used autos sold off heavily in early trading after it reported a fifth straight quarter of shrinking profit margins. Gross margin fell 0.6 percentage point to 13.7% in the…

The pressure is on CarMax (KMX) to post strong numbers when it announces fourth-quarter results Thursday morning. The new and used vehicle chain will report results amid a hot auto market. U.S. automakers delivered strong March sales Tuesday, especially for small, fuel-efficient vehicles. Analysts forecast total U.S. sales to hit an annualized pace of 14.75 million vehicles for the month,…
Stocks continued to work off losses in late trading Wednesday.
The Dow came close to the unchanged mark, thanks to a boost from Alcoa (AA). Meanwhile, the Nasdaq fell 0.6%, up from a 1.1% loss. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 fell 0.3% each.

Jinko Solar (JKS) reversed from a fresh record high and fell 3% in heavy trading. The May IPO was on pace to snap a seven-session win streak. Jinko has nearly tripled since clearing a cup-with-handle base July 7.
Group mate STR Holdings (STRI) dropped 5% and neared its 200-day moving average.

On the upside, CarMax (KMX) gapped up and climbed 8% to a near five-month high. Before the open, the used car retailer delivered fiscal Q2 results above views. The stock neared a 26.60 buy point in a cup base.

Software maker Red Hat (RHT) and research firm IHS (IHS) will report earnings after the close.Stocks continued to work off losses in late trading Wednesday.The Dow came close to the unchanged mark, thanks to a boost from Alcoa (AA). CarMax (KMX) reported profit below Wall Street estimates on Thursday, sending shares down in early afternoon trading.
The new- and used-car chain said second-quarter EPS was flat at 48 cents, below analyst expectations of 52 cents. Sales rose 7% to $2.76 billion, above views of $2.75 billion.
Shares fell nearly 7% intraday to 29.81.
Rival America's Car-Mart (CRMT) also declined 1.5% and major auto dealership owner Penske Automotive Group (PAG) dipped less than 0.5%.
"We are pleased with our improved retail sales in the second quarter, as used unit comps strengthened and we continued to open new stores," said CarMax CEO Tom Folliard.
Used vehicle sales climbed 8% and same-store sales rose 5%. Units sales of wholesale vehicles fell 2% on the year.
Gross profit widened to $368 million from $354.3 million as profit from used vehicles offset a drop in profit from wholesale and new sales.

During August, total U.S. car and truck sales surged 20% vs. a year ago. Chrysler Group reported a 14% rise in sales, Ford (F)reported a 13% jump and General Motors (GM) sales climbed 10%. Japanese carmakers also did well in August vs. their Japan earthquake and tsunami drops in 2011. Honda (HMC) rose 60% and Toyota (TM) jumped 46%.
The Retail/Wholesale-Automobile group is ranked No. 43 out of Investor's Business Daily's 197 industry groups.

Stocks dropped more than 2% in heavy volume Thursday after a poor manufacturing report in China and as the market continued reacting to the Fed's bond . The S&P 500 dived 2.3%, breaching the 1600 level. The Nasdaq slumped 2.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 2.2%, with all 30 components lower. Volume was vastly higher across the board in…

Major averages suffered sharp percentage declines, and growth stocks got nailed, one day after Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke said the Federal Reserve could start scaling back its monthly bond purchases by year-end.

Stocks never found their footing after a weak open Thursday. The S&P 500 lost 2.5% while the Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq gave up 2.3%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in much higher than Wednesday.
All three major averages closed below their 50-day moving averages and took out their June 6 intraday lows.
The CBOE Volatility Index, a popular fear gauge, spiked 27%.

In the stock market today, homebuilders underperformed on fear that borrowing costs will continue to rise. The iShares Dow Jones U.S. Home Construction Index Fund (ITB) lost 6% in more than double-average trade. It closed just above its 200-day moving average.

Meanwhile, several growth names faced intense selling pressure. Two leading mortgage servicers took it on the chin. Ocwen Financial (OCN) and Nationstar Mortgage Holdings (NSM) fell 5% and 6%, respectively. Both names closed above their 50-day moving averages.
Ambarella (AMBA) slumped 7% in heavy turnover. While many growth names have slipped below recent buy points, the chip designer is still holding above a base-on-base buy point of 16.10.

Stratasys (SSYS) was a bright spot. Shares bucked the trend, rising 0.8%. Late Wednesday, the company announced an acquisition that wasn't entirely unexpected. It's buying 3D printer firm MakerBot in a deal initially valued at $403 million.

In earnings news, grocery chain Kroger (KR) dived below its 50-day moving average, falling 6% in heavy volume. Earlier today, first-quarter profit came in above expectations, but sales growth disappointed amid mounting competition.

In economic news, weekly jobless claims rose more than expected last week to 354,000, but the Philadelphia Fed's Business Outlook Survey, a gauge of manufacturing activity in the Mid-Atlantic region, smashed estimates with a strong reading of 12.5. It was the highest reading since April 2011. May existing-home sales also came in better than expected.
The U.S. Dollar Index added 0.5% to 81.86, hurting gold and oil prices. At the New York Mercantile Exchange, August gold tumbled $87.80 to $1,286.20 an ounce. July gold shed $2.84 to $95.40 a barrel.
After the close, earnings from business software giant Oracle (ORCL) disappointed. After losing 3% during the regular session, shares fell an additional 4.5% in after-hours trading.

Investors were in a cheery mood again Tuesday, thanks to a tame reading on consumer inflation as well as optimism about the prospects for soothing words from Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke when the two-day Fed meeting concludes on Wednesday.
The Fed statement will be released at 2 p.m. ET with a press conference scheduled for 2:30 p.m. ET.
The Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq gained 0.9% each. The S&P 500 added 0.8%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming slightly lower than Monday.
In economic news, overall consumer prices rose 0.1% in May. Core prices, which exclude food and energy costs, rose 0.2%. Year-over-year, prices rose 1.4% with the core rate up 1.7%.

In the stock market today, Proto Labs (PRLB) was the best gainer in the IBD 50, rising 5% in fast turnover. The stock cleared a flat-base buy point of 59.94 but is now 4% past the buy point. The company's proprietary technology enables the rapid development of parts, typically in the early stages of development, with the use of 3D computer-automated design software tools.

Elsewhere, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) picked up 4% in light volume. The stock has been consolidating gains for just over five weeks and is still below the 10-week moving average. A new base could eventually take shape, but at this point it would be a sixth-stage base after a big price move already. Regeneron's flagship drug is Eylea, used to treat age-related wet macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly.
Oil services firm Oceaneering (OII), meanwhile, continued to firm up at its 10-week moving average for the first time after a breakout in late April. Shares rose 1% in soft turnover.
Another oil services firm did well. Core Laboratories (CLB) hit an all-time high, soaring 3% in above-average volume.
Finally, China-based Internet and online game services provider NetEase (NTES) added 0.6% in average volume. It's just underneath a potential buy point of 65.18.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, August gold settled at $1,366.90 an ounce, down $16.20 or 1.2%. July oil gained 67 cents to $98.44 a barrel.
Here's a look at some earnings reports due for the rest of the week.
Wednesday: FedEx (FDX), Micron Technology (MU), Red Hat (RHT)
Thursday: Kroger (KR), Pier 1 Imports (PIR), Oracle (ORCL), Tibco Software (TIBX)

A new base could eventually take shape, but at this point it would be a sixth-stage base after a big price move already. Regeneron's flagship drug is Eylea, used to treat age-related wet macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly.Oil services firm Oceaneering (OII), meanwhile, continued to firm up at its 10-week moving average for the first time after a breakout in late April. Shares rose 1% in soft turnover.Another oil services firm did well. Core Laboratories (CLB) hit an all-time high, soaring 3% in above-average volume.Finally, China-based Internet and online game services provider NetEase (NTES) added 0.6% in average volume. It's just underneath a potential buy point of 65.18.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, August gold settled at $1,366.90 an ounce, down $16.20 or 1.2%. July oil gained 67 cents to $98.44 a barrel.Here's a look at some earnings reports due for the rest of the week.Wednesday: FedEx (FDX), Micron Technology (MU), Red Hat (RHT)Thursday: Kroger (KR), Pier 1 Imports (PIR), Oracle (ORCL), Tibco Software (TIBX)Friday: CarMax (KMX), Darden Restaurants (DRI)
Major averages slumped in higher volume Wednesday after the Fed sounded more optimistic about the economy, but continued with its $85 billion in monthly bond purchases.
At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 slumped 1.4%. The Nasdaq gave up 1.1%. Preliminary data showed NYSE volume coming in 18% higher than Tuesday. Nasdaq volume rose 4%.
The yield on the 10-year note surged 13 basis points to 2.32%.

The Fed said that downside risks to the economy have "diminished since the fall." It now sees the unemployment falling to as low as 6.5% by 2014 instead of 2015. The Fed forecast U.S. economic growth of 3% to 3.5% next year and 2.9% to 3.6% in 2015. The consensus among committee members is that the Fed will start to scale back asset purchases by the end of the year.

The damage to leading growth stocks was minimal. In the stock market today, several IBD 50 firms turned in solid performances despite a weak tape. Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) hit a new high, rising 3% in average trade. Its current consolidation is only four-and-a-half weeks old so today wasn't a base breakout.
MercadoLibre (MELI) also outperformed, rising 2%. Volume was slightly above average. It's firming up at its 10-week moving average for the first time after a recent breakout.
And Proto Labs (PRLB) extended gains after Tuesday's breakout from a flat base. Shares rose 2% in above-average turnover. It's now 7% past a buy point of 59.94.

Elsewhere, Netflix (NFLX) added to Tuesday's gains, rising 1% in light volume. Yesterday the online streaming video service announced its largest content deal ever with Dreamworks Animation (DWA). Netflix is finding support at its 10-week line after four straight low-volume weekly price declines.

Tesla Motors (TSLA) fought back after earlier losses and rose 1% in soft volume after the company said it's voluntarily recalling some of its Model S luxury electric cars due to a defect in the mounting bracket of the rear seat.

In earnings news, Adobe Systems (ADBE) jumped 6% in strong volume. Late Tuesday, the company reported its second straight quarter of declining earnings and sales growth, but investors are optimistic about the software maker's move into the cloud. Headed into this week, it showed four straight closes below the 10-week moving average, but it's back above the line, only 2% from a 52-week high.

Buyers also came into FedEx (FDX) as shares rose 1% in heavy turnover. The world's No. 2 delivery company behind UPS (UPS) reported a 7% rise in quarterly profit, helped by strength at its ground shipping service. Sales rose 4% to $11.4 billion, slightly below expectations, but operating margin improved to 9.6% from 9% a year earlier.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, August gold ended at $1,374 an ounce, up $7.10. July oil eased 20 cents to $98.24 a barrel.
Here's a look at some earnings reports on tap for the rest of the week.
Thursday: Kroger (KR), Pier 1 Imports (PIR), Oracle (ORCL), Tibco Software (TIBX)

Buyers came into the market Monday but indexes gave back some of their earlier gains after the Financial Times reported that Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke is likely to signal the Fed is close to tapering down its $85 billion-a-month in bond purchases.
The bulls, however, maintain the Fed still has lingering concerns about the economy and won't say anything to rattle the market when its two-day meeting concludes on Wednesday.

The Nasdaq and S&P 500 gained 0.8% each after being up by as much as 1.3% and 1.2% respectively. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.7%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in about 8% higher than Friday.
Tumbleweeds blew through the after-hours session with little in the way of headline flow.
In the stock market today, Netflix (NFLX) jumped 7% in slightly above-average volume after the streaming video service announced a content licensing agreement with DreamWorks (DWA).

Meanwhile, fundamentals are a bit suspect at Wynn Resorts (WYNN), but the stock recently found support at its 10-week moving average for the first time since breaking out of a base in April. Shares rose 2% in above-average trade after RBC Capital Markets said gambling revenue was strong in Macau during the first half of June.

Inside the IBD 50 list of top-rated growth stocks, Proto Labs (PRLB) extended its winning streak to three sessions, rising 4% in average volume. It closed just below a potential flat-base buy point of 59.94.

Elsewhere, TripAdvisor (TRIP) completed a three-weeks-tight pattern last week. Now it's just a question if the stock can muster a breakout over a buy point of 65.51. Shares rallied 1% in light turnover. It's about 2% from the buy point.

Other names in the IBD 50 continue to show good technical action. MercadoLibre (MELI), Oceaneering International (OII) and Yandex (YNDX) are all firming up at their 10-week lines for the first time after breaking out.

In economic news, homebuilder confidence hit a seven-year high, according to the latest reading from the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market index. It surged to 52 in June from 44 in May, easily topping forecasts for 45. IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial group gained about 2% on the day. Homebuilders aren't in buying range at the moment because all have pulled back sharply off recent highs.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, August gold lost $4.50, or 0.3%, to settle at $1,383.10 an ounce. July crude oil ended at $97.77 a barrel, down 8 cents.
Here's a look at some earnings reports due the rest of the week.
Tuesday: Adobe Systems (ADBE)
Wednesday: FedEx (FDX), Micron Technology (MU), Red Hat (RHT)
Thursday: Kroger (KR), Pier 1 Imports (PIR), Oracle (ORCL)

Buyers had the upper hand again Tuesday as the Dow hit a fresh all-time high on an intraday basis. The S&P 500 hit an intraday high of 1,573.89, just below its October 2007 intraday high of 1,576. Tech stocks outperformed with the Nasdaq up 0.5%. The Dow and S&P 500 added 0.4% each. Preliminary data showed a modest accumulation day…
5:15 p.m. Update:  Stocks finished mixed on this quadruple-witching Friday. Despite a soft outlook from Research In Motion, techs scored some gains. Blue chip issues backed off.

The Nasdaq rallied 1.1%, still off the session high of 1.7%. Apple (AAPL), Baidu.com (BIDU) and Google (GOOG) scored nice gains. Software giant Microsoft (MSFT) rose more than 2% to an eight-month high after Goldman Sachs added the stock to its Conviction Buy List. Research In Motion (RIMM) dropped 5% and breached its 50-day moving average.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite and S&P 500 gained 0.5% and 0.3%, respectively. The Dow fell 0.2%.
With the expiration of options and futures, volume jumped on both exchanges.

Perfect World (PWRD) gapped up and surged 10% to a new 52-week high. The Chinese online gaming firm raised its Q2 sales outlook, citing better-than-forecast demand for its "Battle of the Immortals" game.
Starent Networks (STAR) gapped up, rallying 8% on positive analyst comments. The wireless network equipment maker snapped a five-session losing streak.
Neutral Tandem (TNDM) rose nearly 6% in heavy trading. On Thursday the stock had regained its 50-day moving average, but in light trade. Volume kicked in Friday.

On the earnings calendar for Monday are Walgreen (WAG) and Smith & Wesson (SWHC). Key economic reports next week are: durable goods orders (Tuesday), FOMC meeting (Wednesday), jobless claims (Thursday) and GDP (Thursday).
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks End Mixed In Heavy Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes closed mixed after a choppy session Friday.
The Nasdaq rallied 1.1%, the NYSE composite 0.5%, the S&P 500 0.3%. The Dow fell 0.2%.
Turnover spiked across the board on quadruple witching.
Financials and HMOs were the session's best performers. Hospitals, oil and school operators stumbled.
3:15 p.m. Update:Stocks Weaken In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Comeback efforts were short-lived as sellers turned up the heat in late trading. Only the Nasdaq and NYSE composite remained higher.
The Dow hit a new session low, down 0.5%. Meanwhile the S&P 500 slipped 0.1% after rising as much as 0.9%. The Nasdaq and NYSE composite were up 0.7% and 0.1%, respectively.
Volume was still tracking higher across the board.
Perfect World (PWRD) gapped up and gained 6% after raising its Q2 sales outlook. But the Chinese Internet gaming firm was up more than 12% at session highs.

Another Chinese firm, AsiaInfo Holdings (ASIA) rose 3% in active trading. The IT products provider pulled back to support at its 50-day moving average Thursday. That's the stock's first trip to the line since its May 19 breakout.
2:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Improve In Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks remained mixed with a couple of hours left in Friday's session, but some buyers came back into the market.
The Dow remained lower, but it pared a 0.3% loss to a 0.1% deficit. The Nasdaq climbed 1%, the NYSE composite 0.5% and the S&P 500 0.3%.
Volume continued to track higher on both exchanges.

Starent Networks (STAR) gapped up and gained 6% in active trading on positive analyst comments. CL King & Associates' Lawrence Harris reiterated an accumulate rating as well as a 25 price target. Harris believes that Starent will benefit from lower smart phone prices. The company provides hardware and software that let carriers deliver multimedia to subscribers.
Energy issues stumbled as crude prices reversed after topping $72 a barrel earlier. July crude lost $1.07 to $70.30 a barrel.
Devon Energy (DVN) and EOG Resources (EOG) fell 4% each. Apache (APA) and Continental Resources (CLR) lost 0.3% apiece.
1:15 p.m. Update: Blue Chips Turn Red
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes turned mixed in early afternoon trading Friday.

The Dow converted a 0.7% gain into a 0.2% loss. Earlier, the blue chip index ran into resistance at its 200-day moving average. Chevron (CVX), Exxon Mobil (XOM), United Technologies (UTX) and IBM (IBM) were the Dow's biggest losers.
Meanwhile, the Nasdaq rose 0.8% and the NYSE composite 0.3%. The S&P 500 was virtually flat.
Turnover was again tracking vastly higher across the board.
Taleo (TLEO) rose 6% to an eight-month high. The maker of talent management software has more than tripled since its November low.
HMS Holdings (HMSY) gapped up, adding 2% to score an all-time high. The stock cleared a 38.38 high-handle buy point Tuesday.

On the downside: Research In Motion (RIMM) extended earlier losses, falling 4%. The stock breached its 50-day moving average. Late Thursday, the BlackBerry maker delivered a mixed Q1 report and gave a lackluster outlook. But early Friday a number of brokers raised their price targets on the stock.
12:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Pull Back In Midday Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Stocks pulled back some at midday Friday after touching new session highs.

The Nasdaq pared a 1.7% gain to 1.4%. Still, the tech-laden index was boosted by heavyweights Apple (AAPL), Microsoft (MSFT) and Oracle (ORCL). Chips issues also showed strength, with the Philadelphia semiconductor index rising 1.6%.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite rose 0.9%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the Dow 0.4%.
Volume was tracking higher as a result of futures and options expiration.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals International (VRX) rose 3% in brisk trade. It's nearing a 24.47 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The drugmaker's pattern has many accumulation weeks. Valeant's earnings grew by triple digits in three of the past four quarters. Analysts see profit surging 144% this period.
RehabCare Group (RHB) added 1% to its best level since January 2008. The stock emerged from a pullback to its 50-day moving average.
On the downside, Strayer Education (STRA) erased early gains and fell 4% in active trading.
11:15 a.m. Update: Stocks Add To Early Gains
BY JONAH KERI
The major indexes continued to trade higher in heavy volume Friday.
The Nasdaq gained 1.6%, the S&P 500 0.9%, the Dow industrials 0.6%, the NYSE composite 1% and the small-cap S&P 600 1.2%.
Volume surged across the board on a day of quadruple-witching options expiration.
NVE Corp. (NVEC) ramped up 2% in twice its normal trade. The maker of spintronic sensors has trended higher since completing its second pullback to its 50-day moving average on May 21.
Sybase (SY) added 1% in above-average volume. The enterprise software maker has edged back above its 50-day line.
A number of Chinese stocks have racked up big gains. China-based jewelry company Fuqi International (FUQI) and online gaming firm Perfect World (PWRD) both vaulted 9% in heavy turnover.
10:15 a.m. Update: Major Indexes Jump In Higher Volume

Stocks ended mixed Tuesday after making a feeble attempt to rebound from a sharp sell-off the prior day. The S&P 500 added 0.2%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.2%.Volume was lower across the board, falling 12% on the NYSE and 8% on the Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.Apple (AAPL) was the Dow's biggest decliner, sinking 2.5%, after Japan's Nikkei newspaper reported that the tech giant would cut production of its 6S and 6S Plus iPhone models by about 30% more than planned in the first three months of the year. The report cited Apple suppliers in Japan and abroad.Apple, a former market leader, is now more than 20% off its 52-week high and its Accumulation/Distribution Rating stands at D-, indicating heavy selling.Elsewhere in the stock market today, Gilead Sciences (GILD) rose nearly 1.3% following positive results for its experimental hepatitis B drug.Semiconductor stocks were among the worst performers in the IBD 50.Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI), which makes semiconductors for the auto, communications and defense industries, lost 3.3%. The stock erased a 12% gain past a 38.69 buy point of a cup-with-handle base, triggering a sell signal.Singapore-based chip designer Avago Technologies (AVGO) dropped 3.4% in light trade as it works on a handle in a long consolidation with a buy point at 149.82.Meanwhile, Smith & Wesson (SWHC) was easily the biggest winner in the IBD 50. Shares jumped 11% after the firearms maker issued bullish guidance late Monday.Monsanto (MON) and RPM International (RPM) are among companies due to report quarterly earnings Wednesday.Economic reports scheduled for Wednesday include the Institute for Supply Management's index of service sector activity for December, factory orders for November, the trade balance for November and minutes from the Federal Reserve's Dec. 16 meeting.Follow Scott Stoddard on Twitter @IBD_SStoddard.
5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks closed mixed in light trade Thursday. A round of better-than-expected economic data boosted most indexes, but the Nasdaq lagged all session long.
The S&P 500 gained 0.8%, down from a session high of 1.2%. The Dow and NYSE composite rose 0.7% each. But the Nasdaq slipped a fraction, and the narrower Nasdaq 100 lost 0.1%.
Volume fell sharply on both exchanges.

Fuqi International (FUQI) reversed early losses and surged 15% in more than twice its average trade. The Chinese jewelry firm snapped a five-session losing streak. Thursday's move erased losses from the prior two sessions and then some.

Taleo (TLEO) climbed nearly 6% in more than double its average volume. The software maker has more than tripled since its November low, but has yet to form a proper base. And the correction in the structure is 80%, too deep.
On the downside, Cubic (CUB) gapped down and lost 7% in heavy trading. Needham & Co. cut the stock to hold from buy. Boenning & Scattergood started coverage with a neutral rating.

Research In Motion (RIMM) fell about 1% during the session, but after the close, shares stumbled 6% following the company's Q1 report. The BlackBerry device maker reported earnings above views, but sales were a bit shy. Its Q2 profit and revenue guidance bracketed analysts' estimates, but investors had higher hopes.
The economic calendar is empty on Friday. CarMax (KMX) and Focus Media (FMCN) will report earnings.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks End Mixed In Light Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
A low-volume session ended with mixed results Thursday. Most averages gained, while the Nasdaq dipped.
The S&P 500 climbed 0.8%, while the Dow and NYSE composite rose 0.7% each. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq eased less than 0.1% as late sellers dragged the tech-laden indexes back into the red.
Volume dropped sharply from Wednesday's levels. Advancers beat decliners 3-to-2 on the NYSE and 7-to-6 on the Nasdaq.
Medical groups perked up for the third straight session. Financials also showed strength. Homebuilders, gold producers and retailers were among the session's worst performing groups.
3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Pare Gains In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
Major indexes remained higher in late trading Thursday, but off the session's best levels.
The S&P 500 was up 0.9%, down from 1.2% at its intraday peak. The NYSE composite and Dow were up 0.8% each. The Nasdaq lagged with a 0.2% gain.
Turnover was again tracking sharply lower across the board.
Research In Motion (RIMM) eased 1% in heavy trading ahead of its earnings report after the close. The BlackBerry maker is expected to earn 94 cents a share on sales of $3.43 billion.

IHS (IHS) reversed earlier gains and dropped 4% in active trading. Late Wednesday, the business information and analysis firm beat views with a 39% jump in Q2 earnings, but its sales missed estimates.
2:15 p.m. Update: Major Indexes Hold Firm In Light Trade
BY JONAH KERI
Stocks continued to trade higher Thursday, though volume remained quiet.
The tech-laden Nasdaq composite rose 0.3%, the Dow industrials 1% and the S&P 500 1.1%. Meanwhile, the NYSE composite climbed 1.1% and the small-cap S&P 600 0.8%.
Volume remained sharply lower across the board.
Tetra Tech (TTEK) ramped up 3% in brisk turnover. The provider of pollution control services is now just 1% off its 52-week high.
Chipmaker STEC (STEC) rose 3% in rapid volume. The stock fell in early trading but is now on track for its second straight upside reversal and third straight gain in above-average volume.

On the downside, China-based hotel operator Home Inns & Hotels (HMIN) slid 2% in nearly twice its normal trade. The stock is on pace for its seventh straight loss. On the plus side, it has found support at its 50-day moving average.
1:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Gain Steam

5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks closed mixed in light trade Thursday. A round of better-than-expected economic data boosted most indexes, but the Nasdaq lagged all session long.The S&P 500 gained 0.8%, down from a session high of 1.2%. The Dow and NYSE composite rose 0.7% each. But the Nasdaq slipped a fraction, and the narrower Nasdaq 100 lost 0.1%.Volume fell sharply on both exchanges.Fuqi International (FUQI) reversed early losses and surged 15% in more than twice its average trade. The Chinese jewelry firm snapped a five-session losing streak. Thursday's move erased losses from the prior two sessions and then some.Taleo (TLEO) climbed nearly 6% in more than double its average volume. The software maker has more than tripled since its November low, but has yet to form a proper base. And the correction in the structure is 80%, too deep.On the downside, Cubic (CUB) gapped down and lost 7% in heavy trading. Needham & Co. cut the stock to hold from buy. Boenning & Scattergood started coverage with a neutral rating.Research In Motion (RIMM) fell about 1% during the session, but after the close, shares stumbled 6% following the company's Q1 report. The BlackBerry device maker reported earnings above views, but sales were a bit shy. Its Q2 profit and revenue guidance bracketed analysts' estimates, but investors had higher hopes.The economic calendar is empty on Friday. CarMax (KMX) and Focus Media (FMCN) will report earnings.4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks End Mixed In Light TradeBY VINCENT MAOA low-volume session ended with mixed results Thursday. Most averages gained, while the Nasdaq dipped.The S&P 500 climbed 0.8%, while the Dow and NYSE composite rose 0.7% each. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq eased less than 0.1% as late sellers dragged the tech-laden indexes back into the red.Volume dropped sharply from Wednesday's levels. Advancers beat decliners 3-to-2 on the NYSE and 7-to-6 on the Nasdaq.Medical groups perked up for the third straight session. Financials also showed strength. Homebuilders, gold producers and retailers were among the session's worst performing groups.3:15 p.m. Update: Indexes Pare Gains In Late TradeBY VINCENT MAOMajor indexes remained higher in late trading Thursday, but off the session's best levels.The S&P 500 was up 0.9%, down from 1.2% at its intraday peak. The NYSE composite and Dow were up 0.8% each. The Nasdaq lagged with a 0.2% gain.Turnover was again tracking sharply lower across the board.Research In Motion (RIMM) eased 1% in heavy trading ahead of its earnings report after the close. Stocks pushed ahead to new session highs near midday Friday. The Nasdaq climbed 1%, the S&P 500 0.9% and the NYSE composite 0.8%. Volume turned mixed. NYSE trade was still tracking higher, while Nasdaq volume turned lower. Spreadtrum Communications (SPRD) was off its session peak, but still up 7% in heavy trading. The stock was up as much as 13%,…

After a day of weak volume gains action was quiet after hours.With no highly rated stocks reporting after the close or before Tuesday's opening bell, investors turn their sights toward economic data.Half an hour before the open, S&P Case-Shiller data will be released. Case-Shiller is the home price index that tracks monthly changes in the value of residential real estate in 20 metropolitan regions.Shortly after the market opens, the Conference Board's consumer confidence index will come out. Analysts expect a reading of 50, up from February's nearly 10-point fall to 46. This was the worst level since the 40.8 in April 2009.Volume Is Missing As U.S. Stocks Make GainsBY PATRICK CAINStocks continued to hold gains, but volume was lower.The Dow was up 0.4%, but all 30 of its components moved in lighter trade. The S&P 500 was also up 0.4%. The Nasdaq rose 0.2%, the NYSE composite 0.6%.Trade was down modestly on the NYSE and sharply on the Nasdaq.STR Holdings (STRI) gapped up and gained 10% to an all-time high. The maker of encapsulants to hold solar modules together cleared a 19.10 buy point on March 17 in heavy trade. Its earnings jumped 200% in the fourth quarter. Analysts expect a 271% earnings pop in the first quarter.Expedia (EXPE) surged 6% higher in twice its normal trade. The online travel firm is shaping the right side of a base. So far, however, the base is filled with distribution. That makes the consolidation more likely to fail.On the downside, Vistaprint (VPRT) was off 4%. The printing company is the fastest-moving component of the IBD 100. Despite the double-volume drop, it seems to be finding support at its 50-day moving average.U.S. Stocks Remain High, But Trade Drops OffBY VINCENT MAOStocks continued to trade on the plus side, but off session highs in afternoon trading Monday.The NYSE composite continued to outperform with a 0.6% gain. Energy and steel stocks boosted the index. The S&P 500 and Dow rose 0.4% each. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq climbed 0.3%, holding near the 2400 level.Nasdaq volume continued to track lower, with the pace subsiding more. NYSE volume has now also turned lower.CarMax (KMX) rose 3% to a 20-month high. It's now 8% past a 23.83 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Credit Suisse raised the used car retailer's 2010 and 2011 earnings estimates.Albemarle (ALB) rose 2% in fast trade. It's on pace to end a three-session pullback. The stock broke out from a cup base earlier this month. Analysts see the chemical maker's earnings surging 152% in the current quarter.On the downside, Bridgepoint Education (BPI) erased opening gains and fell 4% in heavy trading. It's on track for its third straight loss. Despite this, the stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has improved to A+ from C+ at the start of the month.G-III Apparel (GIII) also lost 4% in brisk turnover. But it remains 20% past a 22.55 buy point from a high handle. The clothing maker bolted 33% last week after delivering a surprising quarterly profit. It is thinly traded.U.S. Stocks Hold Ground On Energy, AerospaceBY ALAN R. ELLIOTTIndexes remained below their highs but comfortably within the upper half of their ranges.The NYSE composite led with a 0.6% gain. The S&P 500 rose 0.5%. The Nasdaq and the Dow chugged along with 0.4% gains each.Trading remained mixed, slightly higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.Energy, boosted by a dollar-driven price surge and a sector upgrade from Goldman Sachs continued to be the leading influence. Aerospace issues also ran ahead of the market after Boeing (BA) reported it completed a key test of its new 787 Dreamliner on Sunday, and Precision Castparts (PCP) received a Goldman Sachs upgrade to buy.HDFC Bank (HDB) climbed 2%. The India-based bank is just below a 139.01 buy point in a double-bottom base. It somewhat thinly traded, moving about 310,000 shares daily.Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) also moved up 2%. The jump puts the beauty and nutritional products maker 6% above a 27.70 buy point. It broke out from a cup-with-handle base earlier this month.Alpha Natural Resources (ANR) popped 4% in big trade. The Appalachian-region coal miner carries an EPS Rating of 83. It is in a 12-week, cup-with-handle base, just below a 54.03 buy point.One energy sector play that didn't benefit was  Dresser-Rand (DRC). The oil and gas equipment maker dropped 2% in extremely heavy trade. The stock had slumped 5% in early trading.Most Indexes Firm Up; Volume Turns MixedBY VINCENT MAOMost major stock indexes hit new session highs after the dollar weakened further.The NYSE composite climbed 0.7%, thanks in part to energy issues. Goldman Sachs upgraded the exploration and production sector to attractive from neutral. Crude climbed $2.47 to $82.47 a barrel as it neared its January peak.Meanwhile, the S&P 500 rose 0.6% and the Dow 0.5%. The Nasdaq gained 0.6% but didn't hit a new intraday high. NYSE trade was tracking higher, but Nasdaq volume turned lower.Atheros Communications (ATHR) rallied nearly 4% as it bounced back from a three-session pullback. The stock is also rebounding from a test of its 50-day moving average. Analysts see the chipmaker's earnings surging 733% in the current quarter.Herbalife (HLF) climbed 4% to an 18-month high. The stock cleared a 45.28 buy point in a cup base. Last month, the nutritional supplements maker reported a 42% rise in Q4 earnings and 23% gain in sales. Those were its first increases in five quarters.On the downside, Finish Line (FINL) reversed from a four-year high and fell 4% in heavy trading. On Friday, the athletic footwear and clothing retailer surged 16% in reaction to late Thursday's strong Q4 earnings.U.S. Stocks Ease Off HighsBY VINCENT MAOStocks remained higher, but slipped off the best levels of the session Monday.The Nasdaq rose 0.5%, down from 0.7% at its session peak. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 also gained 0.5% each. The Dow gained 0.4%.Volume was tracking higher on both exchanges.China Yuchai (CYD) gapped up and bolted 15% on an upbeat Barron's article. The stock cleared a low handle in a deep cup base. China Yuchai makes diesel engines for trucks and buses.Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) rallied 4% to its best levels since Nov. 2007. It's now 19% past a 20 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The Israeli maker of connectivity products reports Q1 earnings April 21. Analysts see profit rising 60% to 24 cents a share.Belden (BDC) rose 4% to a five-month high. The stock cleared a 25.02 buy point from a base-on-base pattern March 23. Analysts see the telecom gear maker's earning jumping 56% in the current quarter. Belden's sales fell in the past six quarters, but are expected to turn up in the current period.On the downside, Vistaprint (VPRT) dropped 4% and briefly breached its 50-day moving average. The stock fell back under a 59.70 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Elsewhere, crude oil climbed $2.03 to $82.03 as the dollar weakened. Gold gained $5.90 to $1110.20 an ounce.U.S. Stocks Rise In Early GoingBY VINCENT MAOStocks opened modestly higher Monday, adding to last week's gains.The Nasdaq, NYSE composite and S&P 500 climbed 0.5% each, while the Dow rose 0.4%.Volume was tracking higher on both exchanges, especially on the Nasdaq.Recent IPO STR Holdings (STRI) gapped up and surged 10% to a new record high. The stock cleared a 19.10 buy point from a cup base on March 17. STR makes encapsulants that hold solar modules together. Its earnings jumped 200% in the fourth quarter. Analysts see a 271% pop in its current quarter profit.Group mate Canadian Solar (CSIQ) ran up 6% and regained its 50-day moving average. And Trina Solar (TSL), which regained its 50-day line Friday, added 5%.Solar stocks heated up Friday after Credit Suisse analysts boosted their global demand expectations for solar panels and systems.Priceline (PCLN) added 2% on an upgrade. Sidoti raised the online travel services provider to buy from neutral and lifted its price target to 350 from 237. That puts the stock 11% past a 231.59 buy point from a cup base.Futures Pare Gains On Economic NewsBY VINCENT MAOFutures eased after mixed economic data, but continued to point to a higher open Monday.Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 10 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures rose 6 points and Dow futures gained 40 points.In economic news, personal spending rose 0.3% in February  the fifth straight monthly increase. The figure matched economists' expectations. January's number was revised to 0.4% from 0.5%.Personal income was unchanged in February vs. expectations for a 0.1% gain.Futures had little reaction to the news.In corporate news, Boeing (BA) edged up more than 1% in the pre-market after it called test results of a 787 Dreamliner "positive". JPMorgan raised the aerospace giant's price target to 80 from 62.Over the weekend, Ford (F) reached a deal to sell its Volvo unit to China's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group for $1.8 billion. Ford bought the Volvo brand back in 1999 for $6.45 billion. Shares fell less than 1% in pre-open trading.Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) gained 3% in the pre-market after it delivered quarterly earnings above views. The egg producer's fiscal Q3 profit climbed 12% from the prior year to $1.45 a share, or 11 cents above views. Revenue edged up to $271.2 million from $270 million a year earlier, below views of $284.6 million. The company declared a quarterly dividend of 48 cents a share.Elsewhere, the dollar fell against the euro, but gained against the yen.Futures Point To Higher OpenBY VANCE CARIAGAStock futures signaled a higher open early Monday as Greece announced plans to deal with its debt load. Futures remained higher even after news hit that suicide bomber blasts in Moscow's subway system killed at least 37 people.S&P 500 futures rose 4.8 points and were above fair value. Dow futures gained 36 points, and Nasdaq 100 futures added 10 points.Greece said it plans to issue a new seven-year bond. It is expected to price the bond in the coming days. European leaders and the International Monetary Fund last week agreed to provide a safety net should Greece or other countries that use the euro fail to raise money by issuing new debt.New readings on personal income and consumer spending are due out at 8:30 a.m EDT. On average, economists expect February personal income rose 0.1% following an identical rise in January, and that consumer spending rose 0.3% last month following a 0.5% increase in January.Elsewhere, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose to 3.88% early Monday from 3.85% late Friday. The dollar was mixed against other currencies. Oil and gold rose.Overseas, Japan's Nikkei 225 stock average fell 0.09%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng rose 0.88%. In afternoon trading, Britain's FTSE 100 declined 0.08%, while Germany's DAX index and France's CAC-40 advanced 0.64% and 0.02%, respectively.
Equity markets are closed Friday. As such, no notable companies are reporting until next week.
However, Friday at 8:30 a.m. employment situation data will be released. On Monday, non-manufacturing ISM data and pending home sales figures will be unveiled shortly after the open.
Volume Is Mixed As Stocks Make Gains All Around

Equity markets are closed Friday. As such, no notable companies are reporting until next week.However, Friday at 8:30 a.m. employment situation data will be released. On Monday, non-manufacturing ISM data and pending home sales figures will be unveiled shortly after the open.Volume Is Mixed As Stocks Make Gains All Around
5:15 p.m. Update: President Obama's call for tighter restrictions on banks sent the market reeling Thursday.

Obama proposed more stringent rules on risk-taking and trading that could hurt banks' profits. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) shed 7%, while Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) gave up 6% each. Goldman Sachs (GS) lost 4%, even though it reported quarterly earnings well above views.
The NYSE composite and Dow dropped 2.1% and 2%, respectively. Both undercut their 50-day moving averages. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 fell 1.9%, closing just above its 50-day line. The Nasdaq lost 1.1%.
All but the S&P 500 are now down for the year.
Turnover surged on both exchanges, giving all the major indexes another distribution day.

Chinese stocks were hit hard after China reported big gains in its GDP growth and inflation. These data added to concerns that the central bank, which has already started to tighten its monetary policy, has more work to do.
A-Power Energy (APWR) erased morning gains and dived 21% in huge volume. The stock sliced its 50-day moving average.
Telestone Technologies (TSTC) also reversed early gains. It tumbled 13% in about twice its average trade.
SmartHeat (HEAT) and China Yuchai International (CYD) sliced their 50-day lines. They dropped 12% and 10%, respectively.

On the upside, F5 Networks (FFIV) rose 3% in more than three times average volume. It cleared a 54.57 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. Late Wednesday, the network applications firm delivered a 30% rise in fiscal Q1 earnings  its best performance in more than two years. Earlier Thursday, Broadpoint AmTech Research raised its rating on the stock to buy from neutral.
In after-hours news, Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) rose 3% after reporting Q4 results that easily beat views.
Google (GOOG) also delivered quarterly results above views. But shares dropped 5% in extended trading.
American Express (AXP) reported Q4 earnings above views, but it slipped in after-hours trading.
No economic reports are due Friday, but General Electric (GE), McDonald's (MCD) and Schlumberger (SLB) are due to report earnings.
Stocks Close Near Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks got slammed Thursday and closed near the worst levels of the session.
The NYSE composite tumbled 2.1%, the Dow 2%, S&P 500 1.9% and Nasdaq 1.1%.
Volume surged across the board.

Big banks were among the biggest losers after President Obama called for tighter restrictions. Steel producers and alternative-energy firms also got rocked. Regional banks and school operators bucked the trend.
Rebound Strengthens In Late Trade
BY VINCENT MAO
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks shaved off more losses after Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass said President Obama's plan to rid banks' proprietary trading would take three to five years to implement.
The Dow and NYSE composite shed 1.8% each. The S&P 500 fell 1.6% and Nasdaq 0.8%.
Volume was again tracking sharply higher across the board.
American Superconductor (AMSC) reversed morning gains, dropped 6% and sliced its 50-day moving average. It has now given back most of the bulk of gains from its December breakout.
CarMax (KMX) gapped down, fell 3% and breached its 50-day line. Last month, the stock cleared a 23.17 buy point from a cup base. But it set off the 8% sell rule earlier Thursday.
Google (GOOG) slipped 1% ahead of its Q4 results after the bell. Analysts see the Internet titan earning $6.50 a share on sales of $4.92 billion.
On the upside, some regional banks bucked the downtrend.
Comerica (CMA), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) and KeyCorp (KEY) all reported smaller-than-expected quarterly losses. They surged 10%, 9% and 8%, respectively.
Indexes Shave Losses In Afternoon Trading
BY VINCENT MAO
2:15 p.m. update: Stocks remained sharply lower in afternoon trading Thursday, but have crawled off their worst levels.
The NYSE and Dow fell 1.8% each. They were down 2.2% and 2.1%, respectively, at their lowest points. Despite the improvement, both were still under their 50-day moving averages.
Meanwhile, the S&P 500 lost 1.7% and the Nasdaq gave up 1%.
Turnover continued to track higher on both exchanges.

Chinese stocks were hit hard after China reported big gains in its GDP growth and inflation. These data added to concerns that the central bank, which has already started to tighten its monetary policy, has more work to do.
Jinpan International (JST) reversed morning gains and tumbled 11%. The stock sliced its 50-day moving average.
Likewise, SmartHeat (HEAT) and China Yuchai International (CYD) sliced their 50-day lines. They slumped 11% and 10%, respectively.
Rino International (RINO) came under pressure for the eighth straight session. Shares fell 6% to a two-month low.
Elsewhere, Cree (CREE) pulled back from Wednesday's 17% surge. Shares slipped 2% in heavy trading.
Joy Global (JOY) tumbled 8% and breached its 50-day line. The stock cleared a 59.40 buy point from a cup base Jan. 8, but triggered the 8% sell rule Thursday.
Stocks Hold Near Lows
BY VINCENT MAO
1:15 p.m. Update: Major stock indexes hovered near session lows in early afternoon trading Thursday.

The Dow and NYSE composite tumbled 2% each, while the S&P 500 lost 1.8%. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq fell a milder 1.2%, thanks to gains in eBay (EBAY) and Seagate Technology (STX). Volume was tracking sharply higher across the board.
Financials were among the hardest hit group after President Obama proposed new restrictions on banks.

Bank of America (BAC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Morgan Stanley (MS) dropped 5% each. Goldman Sachs (GS) reversed earnings-inspired gains and also fell 5%. The Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) lost nearly 3%, breaching its 50-day moving average.
Precision Castparts (PCP) dropped 4% and sliced its 50-day moving average in heavy trade. Before the open, the aerospace parts maker reported a bigger-than-expected drop in Q3 profit.
Harbin Electric (HRBN) erased earlier gains and slumped 9% in fast trade. It fell to a two-month low. The stock cleared a square-box base earlier this month, but that breakout quickly failed.

On the upside, F5 Networks (FFIV) was off its best levels, but still up 4%. It also cleared a 54.57 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. Late Wednesday, the network applications firm delivered fiscal Q1 results above views. Thursday morning, Broadpoint AmTech Research raised shares to buy from neutral.
Stocks' Losses Intensify At Midday
BY JONAH KERI
12:15 p.m. Update: President Obama's speech detailing the government's planned tougher regulation of U.S. banks sent financial stocks tumbling, adding to the market's woes Thursday.

The S&P 500 fell 1.8%, the Dow and NYSE composite 2% each, the Nasdaq 1.2%. Volume turned higher across the board. It rose 25% on the NYSE and 20% on the Nasdaq compared with the same period Wednesday.
Bucyrus (BUCY) tumbled 6% in twice its normal trade. The mining equipment maker has fallen 11% from its Jan. 11 high. But the stock retains a 96 Relative Price Strength Rating.
ArcSight  (ARST) skidded 4% in above-average volume. The security management software maker's stock sliced through its 50-day moving average, one of several top-rated names to do so Thursday.

Telestone Technologies (TSTC) swooned 15% in huge turnover. The China-based maker of repeaters, antennas and other radio peripherals was one of several leading Chinese stocks to fall in heavy volume this morning.
Banks Lead Growing Morning Losses

Shares of Carmax (KMX) soared as much as 11.5% in early trading Monday after a report said the largest used-car dealership chain's revenue will rise 17% this quarter vs. last year.
The report on Carmax, by Theflyonthewall.com citing data from ITG Research, said CarMax is likely to top analysts' consensus estimate when it announces third quarter results in December.

Carmax is in the highly-ranked Retail-/Wholesale-Automotive group, the top-performer Monday morning. The group has a Relative Strength rating of A-. IBD grades a stock's industry group on a scale of A to E, with A being the best.
The top-rated companies in the group are Lithia Motors (LAD), Penske Automotive Group (PAG), Autonation (AN), Asbury Automotive (ABG) and Group 1 Automotive (GPI).
Although it's the biggest by sales, CarMax performance has lagged its peers, but retail revenue growth is accelerating.

Consensus of 15 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters prior to Monday's report was that Carmax will report Q3 EPS of 38 cents, up 5.6% from the same quarter last year. Revenue was forecast to rise 7.5% to $2.43 billion.
Last quarter the company missed EPS forecasts and just barely topped on revenue, as EPS fell to 48 cents from 49 cents and revenue climbed 6.6% to $2.76 billion, edging estimates of $2.75 billon.
Auto sales data last Tuesday showed U.S. auto sales in September hit a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 14.96 million.

U.S. automakers posted strong sales, driven by new designs and more attractive small-car offerings, reports said.Shares of Carmax (KMX) soared as much as 11.5% in early trading Monday after a report said the largest used-car dealership chain's revenue will rise 17% this quarter vs. last year.The report on Carmax, by Theflyonthewall.com citing data from ITG Research, said CarMax is likely to top analysts' consensus estimate when it announces third quarter results in December.Carmax is in the highly-ranked Retail-/Wholesale-Automotive group, the top-performer Monday morning. Shares of auto retailers AutoNation (AN) and Group 1 Automotive (GPI) tumbled hard Thursday after they reported disappointing third-quarter results before the open. Lithia Motors (LAD), the highest-rated company in the group, also plunged amid a sector sell-off, even though it reported strong Q3 profit and sales gains late Wednesday. The reports come amid continuing uncertainty prior to national elections…
With earnings season right around the corner, analysts are trimming their forecasts to realistic expectations.
But the companies featured on the Leaders With Rising Estimates Screen Of The Day are seeing analysts raise their estimates.
Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) only makes one drug, Soliris, which is used to treat two rare blood diseases.

While Alexion has cornered the market with its drug, it's looking to expand its uses. On Tuesday, the company announced positive results from a phase two study of its use on a third disease, a rare neurological disorder that leads to weakness, paralysis and death.
Analysts expect Alexion earnings to jump 27% on the quarter.
It closed at a new high of 118.15 on Oct. 5, but has retreated modestly since then.
Shares fell 0.7% Friday intraday.
CommVault's (CVLT) Simpana software suite provides backup, restoration and archive solutions to the federal government.
Analysts are expecting the company to report a 17% rise in earnings when it announces results on Oct. 30.
Shares fell 0.1% Friday afternoon.

Generac Holdings (GNRC) produces home generators. On Oct. 1, the company raised its third-quarter outlook to 72-77 cents, citing an increased demand for home and portable generators due to major power outages. Analysts now expect 75 cents.
Shares shot up more than 9% on that earnings upside. The stock has moved sideways since then, climbing 2.5% Friday afternoon.
Shares are hovering around its new high.

Lithia Motors (LAD) operates automotive franchises of new and used vehicles and services. Car sales overall have been doing well and Lithia's competitors have been receiving upgrades, boosting the entire industry.
On Monday Theflyonthewall.com, citing data from ITG Research, said CarMax (KMX) is poised to beat analysts' estimates in Q3.
Lithia closed at a new high on Monday of 36.51.
Analysts are expecting Lithia to post a 26% rise in Q3 earnings when it reports Oct. 24.
Shares edged lower Friday afternoon.
Salesforce.com (CRM) makes customer relationship management software. It's a pioneer in software-as-a-service. Analysts are expecting current-quarter earnings to fall 6%.
Shares edged up 0.2% Friday intraday.

Rackspace Hosting (RAX) is a cloud-computing company who designed its OpenStack software for Fortune 500 companies. On Wednesday, an analyst at William Blair & Co. said the company will likely get more business from Wal-Mart (WMT). Rackspace closed at a new high on Oct. 5 of 69.17. Analyst see its EPS rising 63% for the quarter.
Shares rose 0.1% Friday intraday.
NetSuite (N) is a provider of software-as-a-service, with customers accessing the software via the cloud as needed. Analysts are expecting the company to report a 20% rise in EPS.

Stocks fell in quiet trading Monday, as the technology sector suffered the biggest losses. For the second straight session, the tech-heavy Nasdaq took the blunt of the selling, falling 0.8%. About six of Monday's 10 worst industry groups belonged to the tech space. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 lost 0.3% each. Volume tumbled on both major exchanges Monday, the…
Stocks suffered moderate losses Wednesday and closed near their session lows, ending a two-day winning streak that had taken the Nasdaq and S&P 500 to multiyear or all-time highs.
The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average all fell about 0.9% on the first day of May. Volume in the stock market today rose slightly across the board, according to early data.

In economic news, the ADP employment report missed expectations. But on the upside, the Fed's latest policy statement offered a bit of hope, according to some observers. The central bank said it could increase or decrease its bond buying, in a shift from prior statements in which policymakers didn't specifically mention an increase. The stock market lifted off its session lows following the Fed statement, but then slumped to fresh lows in the session's final minutes.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) was the biggest winner. The developer of drugs for eye diseases and other conditions surged 10% in huge volume, reaching a new high. It got a lift from news of delays for an experimental eye drug from rival Allergan (AGN), which slid 13% and sliced through its 50-day moving average.Stocks suffered moderate losses Wednesday and closed near their session lows, ending a two-day winning streak that had taken the Nasdaq and S&P 500 to multiyear or all-time highs.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average all fell about 0.9% on the first day of May. It got a lift from news of delays for an experimental eye drug from rival Allergan (AGN), which slid 13% and sliced through its 50-day moving average.
The major indexes closed with solid gains and near session highs, as turnover increased from Tuesday's levels on both the NYSE and Nasdaq.
The major indexes closed with solid gains and near session highs, as turnover increased from Tuesday's levels on both the NYSE and Nasdaq.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video!

The NYSE composite rose 0.9%. The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 pushed 0.7% higher. The Nasdaq finished above its 50-day moving average for the second day in a row, while the NYSE and S&P 500 have ended above that level for five straight sessions. Most of IBD's 197 industry groups advanced.

After the bell, Mosaic (MOS) reported earnings for its fiscal Q3 that topped analysts' forecasts. Revenue missed estimates. The fertilizer giant will host a conference call to discuss its results Thursday morning. In a news release, Mosaic said: "Record demand combined with supply uncertainties are serving to support crop nutrient markets." The stock was little changed in extended trading, after initially rising after the bell. Mosaic has regained its 10-week moving average as it etches a choppy consolidation. It has a respectable IBD Composite Rating of 88.

During the regular session, Rackspace Hosting (RAX) jumped 8% in strong volume, clearing a 40.72 buy point from a cup base. The stock finished 6% past that level, meaning it's no longer in a proper buying range. Rackspace, which has a 96 Composite Rating, provides dedicated server hosting and other services.

Tal International (TAL) tacked on 6% in huge trade. The provider of freight containers broke out past a 37.33 buy point from a square-box base last Thursday, but it ended the day below that level and pulled back through Tuesday. On Wednesday, Tal moved back above 37.33. It has a 97 Composite Rating.

Among the companies expected to report earnings Thursday are Lawson Software (LWSN), Robbins & Myers (RBN) and CarMax (KMX). The day's economic news will include the March reading for the Chicago purchasing managers index, as well as February data for factory orders.

Stocks started off a holiday-shortened week on a mixed note Monday, despite a round of buyout news.
Stocks started off a holiday-shortened week on a mixed note Monday, despite a round of buyout news.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video!

The S&P 500 and Nasdaq touched multiyear highs, rising 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. The NYSE composite edged up 0.1%, while the Dow slipped 0.1%. Volume fell sharply on both major exchanges. Friday's turnover was boosted by quadruple witching. Decliners edged out advancers on the NYSE and the Nasdaq. Volume is expected to remain light ahead of the Christmas holiday.
Some leaders showed good action.

InterDigital (IDCC) gapped up and bolted 9% to its best levels since February 2000. The stock has gained 16% since clearing a 36.91 buy point from a square-box base Dec. 8. InterDigital, which makes modems and integrated circuits, won a favorable mention on Friday's "Mad Money."

Amazon.com (AMZN) rose 3%, a record high, in heavy trading. It cleared a 181.94 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. The Web retailer's earnings growth slowed for four quarters. Analysts see bottom-line growth decelerating into single digits this period.

Amtech Systems (ASYS) rallied 6% to a new record high. Volume increased 23% above average. The stock broke out from a cup base Aug. 17 and recently rebounded off its 10-week moving average. Amtech makes production equipment for the solar and semiconductor markets. It has delivered triple-digit sales in two of the past four quarters.

After the close, Adobe Systems (ADBE) reported Q4 earnings of 56 cents a share, up 44% and 4 cents above views. Sales also topped views, and the Acrobat and Photoshop programs gave an upbeat Q1 profit outlook. Shares jumped 6% in extended trading.

Jabil Circuit (JBL) rose 3% in after-hours trading after reporting Q1 earnings that nearly doubled. The contract electronics maker earned 61 cents a share, up 91% from a year ago. It beat views by 7 cents. Sales also beat estimates, and Jabil guided fiscal Q2 results above consensus estimates.
Earnings Tuesday: CarMax (KMX), Finish Line (FINL), Nike (NKE), Red Hat (RHT) and Tibco Software (TIBX).

5:15 p.m. Update: A day of broad gains across global markets left the Nasdaq composite at its highest mark in 13 weeks. The NYSE composite, Dow and S&P 500 all grabbed eight-week highs.
Crude oil, natural gas, copper and other commodities rocked higher in a revival of global risk appetite. Gold slipped below $910 an ounce, the dollar fell, and global bond markets took a beating.

Economic data due out Friday include nonfarm payroll and unemployment numbers scheduled for release from the Department of Labor before the market opens. The Institute for Supply Management plans to release its ISM Services Index at 10 a.m. EDT.
Electrical equipment and galvanized steel producer AZZ (AZZ) is the only report due out on Friday's earnings calendar.

Handheld device and smart phone maker Research In Motion(RIMM) jumped 8% in after hours trading. The maker of BlackBerry devices said Q4 earnings were 90 cents per share, up 25% over the prior year and six cents above analyst consensus. The gap up move put the stock back above its 10-week moving average, but shares remain deep in a nine month correction.
4:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Close With Another Sharp Increase
BY JUAN CARLOS ARANCIBIA
The market gave back some gains but still finished with another sharp advance.
The NYSE composite surged 3.6%, the Nasdaq 3.3%, the S&P 500 2.9% and the Dow 2.8%.
Preliminary data showed volume swelled, solidifying the day's gains.
Although Thursday's news benefited financials the most, it wasn't the top sector.
Cyclicals such as machinery, transportation and metals marked the best industry gains.
Auto-related groups also led after better-than-expected auto sales in the U.S. and Europe.
3:15 p.m. Update: Stocks Near Highs In Late Trade
